Quiz Results

Part 2 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 11-20)
← Prev Part 2 of 85 Next →

Quiz Attempt #118897

Total Questions: 48
Question 1
Consider the following steps:1. Banking Department gets currency from the Issue Department.2. Government puts the currency in circulation.3. Central Government incurs a deficit in its Budget.4. Government Sells Treasury Bills to Banking Department of RBI.Which among the following is the correct order of the above steps?
  • A.1 2 3 4
  • B.2 3 4 1
  • C.3 4 1 2
  • D.4 3 2 1
Correct Answer: 3 4 1 2

The correct order is given below:

(i) Central Government incurs a deficit in its Budget.

(ii) Government Sells Treasury Bills to Banking Department of RBI.

(iii) Banking Department gets currency from the Issue Department.

(iv) Government puts the currency in circulation.

 

Role of RBI as Currency Authority:

The issue of notes by the RBI is kept separate from the rest of its banking operations. For this, the RBI is organized under two separate departments, the Issue Department and the Banking Department, the former being solely responsible for the issue of notes. The issue of currency into circulation and its withdrawal from circulation (i.e., expansion and contraction of currency respectively) take place through the Banking Department of the RBI. The mechanics is explained below:

 

When the Central Government incurs a deficit in its budget and borrows from the RBI by selling treasury bills to the Banks’ Banking Department, the latter pays cash by either drawing down its stock of currency and/or by getting currency from the Issue Department against equivalent transfer of eligible assets. The government by spending new currency puts it into circulation.

Question 2
One of the well-known market analysts made this statement: “We expect the Reserve Bank of India to continue to ease liquidity” Which among the following instruments can be used by RBI to continue to ease liquidity?1. Cutting the frequency of Open Market Operations.2. Cutting the Cash Reserve Ratio.3. Cutting the Repo and Reverse Repo rates.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.Only 1
  • B.1 & 2
  • C.2 & 3
  • D.1, 2 & 3
Correct Answer: 2 & 3

Repo Rate: The interest rate at which the Reserve Bank provides overnight liquidity to banks against the collateral of government and other approved securities under the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF).

 

Reverse Repo Rate: The (fixed) interest rate at which the Reserve Bank absorbs liquidity, on an overnight basis, from banks against the collateral of eligible Government Securities under the LAF.

 

Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF): The LAF consists of overnight as well as term repo auctions. Progressively, the Reserve Bank has increased the proportion of liquidity injected under fine-tuning variable rate repo auctions of range of tenors. The aim of term repo is to help develop the inter-bank term money market, which in turn can set market based benchmarks for pricing of loans and deposits, and hence improve transmission of monetary policy. The Reserve Bank also conducts variable interest rate reverse repo auctions, as necessitated under the market conditions.

 

Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR): The average daily balance that a bank is required to maintain with the Reserve Bank as a share of such per cent of its Net demand and time liabilities (NDTL) that the Reserve Bank may notify from time to time in the Gazette of India. Cutting the CRR enhance the credit capacity of the banks and consequently increase liquidity.

 

So, cutting the CRR, Repo and Reverse Repo rates will increase the money with the banks which will increase their liquidity and capacity to lend to the public.

 

Open Market Operations (OMOs): These include both, outright purchase and sale of government securities, for injection and absorption of durable liquidity, respectively. Cutting frequency of OMO will reduce RBI’s ability to affect liquidity in the market.

Question 3
Consider the following statement regarding concept of money:1. M1= Money with the Public (currency notes and coins) + Demand deposits of banks (on current and saving bank accounts) + Other demand deposits with RBI.2. M2= M1 + Saving bank deposits with Post-offices.3. M3= M2 + Net time deposits of commercial banks4. M4= M3 + All deposits of Post-offices including National Savings CertificatesWhich among the following are correct?
  • A.1, 2, 3 and 4
  • B.1, 2 and 3
  • C.1, 3 and 4
  • D.1, 2 and 4
Correct Answer: 1, 2 and 3

Money Supply

The measures of money supply in India are classified into four categories M1, M2, M3 and M4 along with M0 (Reserve Money).

 

Reserve Money (M0):

It is also known as High-Powered Money, Monetary Base, Base Money etc.

M0 = Currency in Circulation + Bankers’ Deposits with RBI + Other deposits with RBI

It is the monetary base of economy.

 

Narrow Money (M1 and M2):

M1 = Currency with public + Demand deposits with the Banking system (current account, saving account)

M2 = M1 + Savings deposits of Post Office Savings Banks

 

Broad Money (M3 and M4):

M3 = M1 + Net time deposits of commercial banks

M4 = M3 + All deposits with Post Office Savings Banks excluding National Savings Certificates

Question 4
The _____ are the total amount of monetary assets available in an economy at a specific time.1. Money Supply2. Money Stock3. Money Demand4. Stock in DemandSelect the correct answer using the code given below:Codes
  • A.1 and 2
  • B.3 and 4
  • C.1 and 3
  • D.2 and 4
Correct Answer: 1 and 2

The money supply or money stock is all the currency and other liquid instruments in a country's economy on the date measured. The money supply roughly includes both cash and deposits that can be used almost as easily as cash.

The Money Supply (M) is sum of CU, DD or Time Deposits changes.

M = CU + DD

where:

CU is currency (notes plus coins) held by the public

DD is net demand deposits held by commercial banks.

 

Money supply, like money demand, is a stock variable. The total stock of money in circulation among the public at a particular point of time is called money supply.

Question 5
_______ are conducted by the RBI through selling and buying government securities from banks.
  • A.Bank rate
  • B.Cash reserve ratio
  • C.Open market operations
  • D.Statutory Liquidity Ratio
Correct Answer: Open market operations

Open Market Operations (OMOs) is a type of RBI's Monetary Policy instrument that include both, outright purchase and sale of government securities, for injection and absorption of durable liquidity, respectively.

Question 6
What is SLR ratio of a bank?
  • A.The ratio of total deposits against total investments.
  • B.The amount deposited by the bank with the Central Bank in the form of cash, gold, and securities.
  • C.The amount that commercial banks are required to maintain before providing credit to customers.
  • D.The amount that commercial banks deposit with foreign banks.
Correct Answer: The amount that commercial banks are required to maintain before providing credit to customers.

Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR): The share of NDTL that a bank is required to maintain in safe and liquid assets, such as unencumbered government securities, cash and gold. Changes in SLR often influence the availability of resources in the banking system for lending to the private sector.

Question 7
The ___________ is a facility under which scheduled commercial banks can borrow additional amount of overnight money from the Reserve Bank by dipping into their Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) portfolio up to a limit at a penal rate of interest. This provides a safety valve against unanticipated liquidity shocks to the banking system.
  • A.Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF)
  • B.Marginal Standing Facility (MSF)
  • C.Reverse Repo Rate
  • D.Repo Rate
Correct Answer: Marginal Standing Facility (MSF)

Marginal Standing Facility (MSF): A facility under which scheduled commercial banks can borrow an additional amount of overnight money from the RBI by dipping into their Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) portfolio up to a limit at a penal rate of interest. This provides a safety valve against unanticipated liquidity shocks to the banking system.

Question 8
The Central Government, in September 2016, constituted the present Monetary Policy Committee MPC. The Chairman of MPC is:
  • A.Finance Minister of the Government of India
  • B.Governor of the Reserve Bank of India
  • C.Secretary of Department of Financial Services
  • D.Deputy Governor of RBI, to be nominated by the Governor of RBI.
Correct Answer: Governor of the Reserve Bank of India

Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)

 

Now in India, the policy interest rate required to achieve the inflation target is decided by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC). The MPC is a 6-member committee constituted by the Central Government.

 

The Central Government, in September 2016, constituted the present MPC as under:

1. Governor of the Reserve Bank of India – Chairperson, ex officio;

2. Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, in charge of Monetary Policy – Member, ex officio;

3. One officer of the Reserve Bank of India to be nominated by the Central Board – Member, ex officio;

4. Shri Chetan Ghate, Professor, Indian Statistical Institute (ISI) – Member;

5. Professor Pami Dua, Director, Delhi School of Economics – Member; and

6. Dr. Ravindra H. Dholakia, Professor, Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad – Member.

 

Members referred to at 4 to 6 above, will hold office for a period of 4 years or until further orders, whichever is earlier.

 

The MPC is required to meet at least 4 times in a year. The quorum for the meeting of the MPC is 4 members. Each member of the MPC has 1 vote, and in the event of an equality of votes, the Governor has a second or casting vote.

 

The resolution adopted by the MPC is published after the conclusion of every meeting of the MPC. Once in every 6 months, the Reserve Bank is required to publish a document called the Monetary Policy Report to explain: (1) the sources of inflation and (2) the forecast of inflation for 6-18 months ahead.

Question 9
Which of the following is not correct about LTRO?
  • A.The RBI introduced LTRO in March 2020.
  • B.Under LTRO, RBI provides short term loans (up to 28 days) to banks at the prevailing repo rate.
  • C.This is done to introduce liquidity in the money market.
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Under LTRO, RBI provides short term loans (up to 28 days) to banks at the prevailing repo rate.

Long Term Repo Operation (LTRO)

In march 2020, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) introduced a tool called Long-Term Repo Operation (LTRO) to inject liquidity in the system, as well as to ensure transmission of rates.

 

Under LTRO, RBI provides longer term (one- to three-year) loans to banks at the prevailing repo rate. The banks provide government securities as collateral. As banks get long-term funds at lower rates, their cost of funds falls. In turn, they reduce interest rates for borrowers. LTRO helped RBI ensure that banks reduce their marginal cost of funds-based lending rate, without reducing policy rates.

 

This helps banks get funds for a longer duration as compared to the short-term (up to 28 days) liquidity provided by the RBI through other tools such as liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) and marginal standing facility (MSF).

 

LTRO is an example that the RBI will not only rely on revising repo rates and conducting open market operations for its monetary policy, but also use new tools to achieve its intended objectives.

Question 10
In order to control inflation and ensure stability in money market: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.The RBI works under the direction of ministry of finance, government of India.
  • B.The RBI acts independently and can refuse the government directive
  • C.The RBI acts under the board of directors.
  • D.The RBI's board of governors shall abide by the government directive.
Correct Answer: The RBI acts independently and can refuse the government directive

In order to control inflation and ensure stability in money market, the RBI acts independently and can refuse the government directive.

Question 11
From the following, identify the tools of Fiscal Policy: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)(i) Public expenditure(ii) Open market operations(iii) Deficit financing(iv) Taxation(v) Reserve requirementsOptions
  • A.(i), (iii), (iv) and (v)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iv) and (v)
  • C.(ii) and (v)
  • D.(i), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii) and (iv)

The tools of Fiscal Policy are – Public Expenditure, Deficit Financing, and Taxation.

 

Fiscal Policy involves the use of government spending, taxation, and borrowing to influence the economy. The government adjusts its fiscal policy to achieve economic goals such as controlling inflation, boosting economic growth, and reducing unemployment.

 

Monetary Policy involves the control and regulation of money supply and interest rates by a country's central bank (RBI). The central bank (RBI) influences economic conditions by manipulating interest rates, open market operations, and reserve requirements.

Question 12
Match the items of List I with items of List II and choose the correct answer from the code given below. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)List I(a) NPA(b) SLR(c) Repo Rate(d) CRRList II(i) The percentage of deposits to be kept with RBI in the form of cash.(ii) The rate at which RBI lends money to commercial banks.(iii) Loans and advances not paid for more than 90 days.(iv) The percentage of net demand and time liabilities to be kept in the form of liquid assets.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i

(a) NPA - Loans and advances not paid for more than 90 days.

A nonperforming asset (NPA) refers to a classification for loans or advances that are in default or are in arrears on scheduled payments of principal or interest. In most cases, debt is classified as nonperforming when loan payments have not been made for a period of 90 days. While 90 days of non-payment is the standard, the amount of elapsed time may be shorter or longer depending on the terms and conditions of each loan.

 

(b) SLR - The percentage of net demand and time liabilities to be kept in the form of liquid

The Reserve Bank of India mandates every bank should have a specific liquid reserve in the form of cash or gold. It is called Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR).

 

Every bank must have a minimum portion of their Net Demand and Time Liabilities (NDTL) in the form of cash, gold or other liquid assets by the day’s end. The ratio of these liquid assets to the demand and time liabilities is called as the Statutory Liquidity Ratio. The Reserve Bank of India has the authority to increase this ratio up to 40%. The increase in this ratio constricts the ability of the bank to inject money into the economy.

 

In India, the Reserve Bank of India is responsible for regulating the supply of money and stability of prices to run the economy. Statutory Liquidity Ratio is one of its many monetary policies for the same. SLR (among other tools) is instrumental in ensuring the solvency of the banks and money flow in the economy.

 

(c) Repo Rate - The rate at which RBI lends money to commercial banks.

Repo rate refers to the rate at which commercial banks borrow money from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in case of shortage of funds. It is one of the main tools of RBI to keep inflation under control. Technically, Repo stands for ‘Repurchasing Option’. It is a contract in which banks provide eligible securities such as Treasury Bills to the RBI while availing overnight loans.

 

There is also a term called Reverse Repo Rate which is a rate that RBI offers to banks when they deposit their surplus cash with RBI for shorter periods. In other words, it is the rate at which the RBI borrows from the commercial banks. When banks have excess funds, but don’t have any other lending or investment options, they deposit/lend the surplus funds with the RBI. This way banks can raise additional interest from their funds.

 

(d) CRR - The percentage of deposits to be kept with RBI in the form of cash.

Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) is the share of a bank’s total deposit that is mandated by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to be maintained with the latter in the form of liquid cash. In order to determine the base rate, the Cash Reserve Ratio acts as one of the reference rates. Base rate means the minimum lending rate which is determined by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and no bank is allowed to lend funds below this rate. This rate is fixed to ensure transparency with respect to borrowing and lending in the credit market. The Base Rate also helps the banks to cut down on their cost of lending so as to be able to extend affordable loans. Apart from this, there are two main objectives of Cash Reserve Ratio:

(i) Cash Reserve Ratio ensures that a part of the bank’s deposit is with the Central Bank and is hence, safe.

(ii) Another objective of CRR is to keep inflation under control. During high inflation in the economy, RBI raises the CRR to lower the bank’s loanable funds.

Question 13
Which one is NOT true regarding the Market Stabilization Scheme (MSS)? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.It absorbs surplus liquidity of enduring nature arising out of large capital flows.
  • B.It absorbs surplus liquidity through sale of short-dated government securities and treasury bills.
  • C.Mobilized surplus liquidity is held in the MSS account with the Reserve Bank of India.
  • D.MSS account liquidity can be used for normal government expenditure of capital nature.
Correct Answer: MSS account liquidity can be used for normal government expenditure of capital nature.

MSS (Market Stabilisation Scheme) securities are issued with the objective of providing the RBI with a stock of securities with which it can intervene in the market for managing liquidity. These securities are issued not to meet the government’s expenditure.

 

The MSS scheme was launched in April 2004 to strengthen the RBI’s ability to conduct exchange rate and monetary management. The bills/bonds issued under MSS have all the attributes of the existing treasury bills and dated securities. These securities will be issued by way of auctions to be conducted by the RBI. The timing of issuance, amount and tenure of such securities will be decided by the RBI.

 

The securities issued under the MSS scheme are matched by an equivalent cash balance held by the government with the RBI. As a result, their issuance will have a negligible impact on the fiscal deficit of the government.

Question 14
What is repo rate? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.It is the rate at which RBI lends to State government.
  • B.It is the rate at which International aid agencies lends to TBI.
  • C.It is the rate at which RBI lends to Banks in case of short maturity.
  • D.It is the rate at which RBI borrows funds from the Commercial Banks in the country.
Correct Answer: It is the rate at which RBI lends to Banks in case of short maturity.

The rate at which RBI lends to Banks in case of short maturity.

Repo rate is the rate at which the central bank of a country (Reserve Bank of India in case of India) lends money to commercial banks in the event of any shortfall of funds. Repo rate is used by monetary authorities to control inflation. In the event of inflation, central banks increase repo rate as this acts as a disincentive for banks to borrow from the central bank. This ultimately reduces the money supply in the economy and thus helps in arresting inflation.

Question 15
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)Statement I:Monetary policy causes a deliberate change in government revenue and expenditure with a view to influencing the price level and the quantum of national output.Statement II:Fiscal policy regulates the money supply and the cost and availability of credit.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect

Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.

Monetary policy is the macroeconomic policy laid down by the central bank. It involves management of money supply and interest rate and is the demand side economic policy used by the government of a country to achieve macroeconomic objectives like inflation, consumption, growth and liquidity.

Fiscal policy refers to the use of government spending and tax policies to influence economic conditions, especially macroeconomic conditions, including aggregate demand for goods and services, employment, inflation, and economic growth.

Question 16
Reverse Repo Rate is a tool used by the Reserve Bank of India primarily to __________.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Inject liquidity
  • B.Absorb liquidity
  • C.Protect bank credit
  • D.Build reserve
Correct Answer: Absorb liquidity

Reverse Repo Rate is a tool used by the Reserve Bank of India primarily to absorb liquidity.

Reverse Repo Rate is a mechanism to absorb the liquidity in the market, thus restricting the borrowing power of investors. Reverse Repo Rate is when the RBI borrows money from banks when there is excess liquidity in the market. The banks benefit out of it by receiving interest for their holdings with the central bank.

Question 17
Which of the following statements is correct relating to Indian Financial System? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.RBI has direct supervision over depositories and mutual funds.
  • B.Monetary control is exercised through cash reserve ratio and statutory liquidity ratio.
  • C.Primary dealers mainly deal in shares, mutual fund units.
  • D.The decrease in statutory liquidity ratio contracts the credit creation.
Correct Answer: Monetary control is exercised through cash reserve ratio and statutory liquidity ratio.

Option B is the correct answer.

Monetary control is exercised through cash reserve ratio and statutory liquidity ratio by the RBI. Hence, statement 2 is correct.

 

SEBI has direct supervision over depositories and mutual funds. Hence, statement 1 is incorrect.

 

Primary dealers are RBI recognized traders who buy and sell government securities and provide underwriting support to the government whenever it seeks to raise funds through bond issues. Hence, statement 3 is incorrect.

 

The decrease in statutory liquidity ratio expands the credit creation. Hence, statement 4 is incorrect.

Question 18
Which of the following is INCORRECT about ways, the RBI can affect the structure of interest rates? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) By changing the treasury bill rate(2) Blending of leading and trading activities(3) By changing the Bank rate(4) Fixing the maximum interest on time deposits with the bank(5) Ineffective tapping and mobilization of savingsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1 and 4 only
  • B.4 and 5 only
  • C.2 and 5 only
  • D.1, 3, 4 and 5 only
Correct Answer: 2 and 5 only

The incorrect statements regarding ways the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) can affect the structure of interest rates are options (2) and (5):

 

(2) Blending of leading and trading activities

(5) Ineffective tapping and mobilization of savings

 

The RBI typically influences interest rates through various monetary policy tools such as changing the Bank rate, Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR), Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR), Open Market Operations (OMO), and other policy measures. The concepts mentioned in options (2) and (5) are not directly related to the traditional tools used by the RBI to influence interest rates, making them incorrect in this context.

Question 19
When the RBI desires to restrict expansion of credit, it: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.increases the bank rate.
  • B.decreases the bank rate.
  • C.decreases the CRR for banks.
  • D.decreases the SLR for banks.
Correct Answer: increases the bank rate.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is responsible for regulating the money supply in the economy and maintaining price stability. One of the tools that the RBI uses to control the money supply is the bank rate.

 

The bank rate is the rate at which the RBI lends money to commercial banks. When the RBI increases the bank rate, it becomes more expensive for commercial banks to borrow money from the RBI, which reduces the amount of funds that banks have available to lend to their customers.

 

When the amount of funds available for lending by banks is reduced, it restricts the expansion of credit in the economy. This is because banks have less money to lend, which leads to higher interest rates and tighter lending standards.

 

Higher interest rates make borrowing more expensive for consumers and businesses, reducing their willingness and ability to take out loans. As a result, the demand for credit decreases, which slows down economic activity and restricts the expansion of credit in the economy.

Question 20
Match List I with List II: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)List I (Interest rates)A. Policy RateB. Repo RateC. MCLRD. Bank RateList II (Description)I. RBI lending rate to commercial banks without security.II. RBI lending rate when commercial banks borrow money by purchasing securities issues byRBI.III. Internal benchmark rate for financial institutions and banks.IV. Rate established by RBI to influence the main monetary variables in the economy.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes :
  • A.A- I, B- IV, C- III, D- II
  • B.A- IV, B- I, C- III, D- II
  • C.A- IV, B- II, C- III, D- I
  • D.A- II, B- IV, C- I, D- III
Correct Answer: A- IV, B- II, C- III, D- I

Policy rate, repo rate, MCLR, and bank rate are all terms used in the context of monetary policy and interest rates.

 

Policy Rate: A policy rate is a benchmark interest rate set by a central bank, such as the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The policy rate serves as a guide for other interest rates in the economy and is used to influence economic activity by controlling the supply of money and credit.

 

Repo Rate: The repo rate is the rate at which the central bank lends money to commercial banks in exchange for collateral. The repo rate is a key tool used by central banks to manage the money supply and influence economic activity. A change in the repo rate affects the cost of borrowing for commercial banks, which can in turn affect interest rates for loans and deposits.

 

MCLR: The Marginal Cost of Funds-based Lending Rate (MCLR) is a benchmark interest rate used by banks in India to determine the interest rates on loans. MCLR takes into account the Bank’s marginal cost of funds (i.e., the cost of borrowing or acquiring funds), operating costs, and a profit margin. MCLR is revised periodically and is based on the current market conditions.

 

Bank Rate: The bank rate is the rate at which the central bank lends money to commercial banks without collateral. The bank rate is typically higher than the repo rate and serves as a long-term benchmark rate. A change in the bank rate can affect interest rates for loans and deposits and can also influence the exchange rate and inflation.

Question 21
Read the passage below carefully and answer the question that follow: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)Capital flows, exchange rates and the interest rates are causes of immediate concern to the national economies. Central banks of various countries have been using a variety of methods with the excessive capital inflows. Foreign portfolio investment has a direct and indirect impact on exchange rates, valuation of traded assets and yields of various government and corporate securities.RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation, is working on multiple options to stabilizethe exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers.One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currency assets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.The retail inflation, according to the RBI Governor, recently is likely to be4.5% in 2023 fiscal. With this perspective, the repo rate and reverse repo rate remain at 4% and 3.35%, respectively, since May 22, 2020. A balancing act between economic growth and inflation is visible. Though the RBI rates are consistent, the burden onborrowers for the short-term and long-term, is still unpredictable.The primary purpose of the monetary policy of RBI is to maintain:
  • A.Wealth
  • B.Exchange Rate Volatility
  • C.Income Equality
  • D.Stability of prices
Correct Answer: Stability of prices

The answer can be derived from

 

“RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation is working on multiple options to stabilize the exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers.

 

One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currency assets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.”

Question 22
Read the passage below carefully and answer the question that follow: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)Capital flows, exchange rates and the interest rates are causes of immediate concern to the national economies. Central banks of various countries have been using a variety of methods with the excessive capital inflows. Foreign portfolio investment has a direct and indirect impact on exchange rates, valuation of traded assets and yields of various government and corporate securities.RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation is working on multiple options to stabilizethe exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers.One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currency assets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.The retail inflation, according to the RBI governor, recently is likely to be4.5% in 2023 fiscal. With this perspective, the repo rate and reverse repo rate remain at 4% and 3.35%, respectively, since May 22, 2020. A balancing act between economic growth and inflation is visible. Though the RBI rates are consistent, the burden onborrowers for the short-term and long-term, is still unpredictable.The stance of a monetary policy wherein the interest rates may move either way, upwards or downwards, is called:
  • A.Accommodative stance
  • B.Neutral stance
  • C.Calibrated stance
  • D.Hawkish stance
Correct Answer: Neutral stance

A neutral stance of monetary policy is a situation where the central bank aims to keep interest rates and other monetary policy tools at a level that neither stimulates nor restricts economic growth. In other words, it is a policy stance that aims to achieve a balance between controlling inflation and promoting economic growth.

 

When a central bank adopts a neutral stance, it typically sets its interest rates at a level that neither encourages nor discourages borrowing and lending activities in the economy. This is because the central bank views the economy as operating at its potential level of output, where there is neither excessive demand nor excess supply.

 

The main aim of a neutral monetary policy is to maintain price stability and ensure sustainable economic growth over the long term. It is believed that by keeping interest rates at a neutral level, the central bank can help stabilize the economy and prevent it from overheating or experiencing a recession.

Question 23
Read the passage below carefully and answer the question that follow: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)Capital flows, exchange rates and the interest rates are causes of immediate concern to the national economies. Central banks of various countries have been using a variety of methods with the excessive capital inflows. Foreign portfolio investment has a direct and indirect impact on exchange rates, valuation of traded assets and yields of various government and corporate securities.RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation is working on multiple options to stabilizethe exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers.One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currency assets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.The retail inflation, according to the RBI governor, recently is likely to be4.5% in 2023 fiscal. With this perspective, the repo rate and reverse repo rate remain at 4% and 3.35%, respectively, since May 22, 2020. A balancing act between economic growth and inflation is visible. Though the RBI rates are consistent, the burden on borrowers for the short-term and long-term, is still unpredictable.An increase in investment is most likely to be caused by:
  • A.Decrease in marginal propensity to consume.
  • B.Expectations of lower GDP.
  • C.Lowering of interest rates.
  • D.Writing-off of Non-performing Assets
Correct Answer: Lowering of interest rates.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

There are many factors that can contribute to an increase in investment, including:

1. Economic conditions: If the overall economy is growing and there is a sense of stability and confidence among investors, it can encourage investment.

2. Interest rates: Lower interest rates can make borrowing cheaper, which can stimulate investment in businesses and other ventures.

3. Government policies: Government policies that provide incentives for investment, such as tax breaks or subsidies, can encourage investors to put their money into particular sectors or industries.

4. Technological advancements: Advances in technology can create new investment opportunities and make existing investments more attractive.

5. Political stability: Political stability can create a more predictable environment for investors, which can encourage investment.

6. Market demand: If there is a strong demand for a particular product or service, it can make investment in that sector more attractive.

7. Investor confidence: Confidence in the overall economy, as well as in specific industries or companies, can encourage investment.

Question 24
Read the passage below carefully and answer the question that follow: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)Capital flows, exchange rates and the interest rates are causes of immediate concern to the national economies. Central banks of various countries have been using a variety of methods with the excessive capital inflows. Foreign portfolio investment has a direct and indirect impact on exchange rates, valuation of traded assets and yields of various government and corporate securities.RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation is working on multiple options to stabilizethe exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers.One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currency assets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.The retail inflation, according to the RBI governor, recently is likely to be4.5% in 2023 fiscal. With this perspective, the repo rate and reverse repo rate remain at 4% and 3.35%, respectively, since May 22, 2020. A balancing act between economic growth and inflation is visible. Though the RBI rates are consistent, the burden onborrowers for the short-term and long-term, is still unpredictable.Quantitative Easing (QE) by the Central bank implies:
  • A.Selling of assets by the Central bank.
  • B.Lowering of interest rates for commercial bank lending.
  • C.Purchase of assets by the Central bank.
  • D.Central bank reducing the policy rate.
Correct Answer: Purchase of assets by the Central bank.

Quantitative Easing (QE) is a monetary policy tool used by central banks to stimulate the economy when traditional monetary policy tools, such as adjusting interest rates, are no longer effective.

 

When a central bank implements QE, it buys financial assets such as government bonds, corporate bonds, or mortgage-backed securities from banks and other financial institutions, which injects money into the economy. This increase in the money supply is intended to lower interest rates, stimulate lending, and encourage investment and spending.

 

QE can also help to boost asset prices, such as stocks and real estate, which can increase household wealth and encourage consumer spending. Additionally, QE can help to increase inflation by encouraging borrowing and spending, which can support economic growth.

 

However, there are also potential risks associated with QE, such as inflationary pressures, asset price bubbles, and a potential increase in the risk-taking behaviour of financial institutions.

 

Central banks typically use QE cautiously and in moderation to balance the benefits and risks of this policy tool.

Question 25
Read the passage below carefully and answer the question that follow: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)Capital flows, exchange rates and the interest rates are causes of immediate concern to the national economies. Central banks of various countries have been using a variety of methods with the excessive capital inflows. Foreign portfolio investment has a direct and indirect impact on exchange rates, valuation of traded assets and yields of various government and corporate securities.RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation is working on multiple options to stabilizethe exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers.One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currency assets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.The retail inflation, according to the RBI governor, recently is likely to be4.5% in 2023 fiscal. With this perspective, the repo rate and reverse repo rate remain at 4% and 3.35%, respectively, since May 22, 2020. A balancing act between economic growth and inflation is visible. Though the RBI rates are consistent, the burden on borrowers for the short-term and long-term, is still unpredictable.Changes in foreign portfolio investments is directly related to
  • A.Money demanded
  • B.Exchange rate
  • C.Prices
  • D.Circulation of money
Correct Answer: Exchange rate

Foreign portfolio investments refer to the investment in the financial assets of a country made by non-residents, such as stocks, bonds, and other securities. The changes in foreign portfolio investments can be directly related to various factors, including:

 

1. Economic conditions: Economic factors such as inflation, interest rates, and growth prospects can influence foreign investors’ decisions to invest in a country’s financial assets.

2. Political stability: Political stability, the rule of law, and government policies can also influence foreign investors’ decisions to invest in a country.

3. Exchange rate: The exchange rate of a country’s currency relative to other currencies can affect the attractiveness of the country’s financial assets to foreign investors.

4. Market sentiment: The overall market sentiment, including investor confidence and risk appetite, can also influence foreign investors’ decisions to invest in a country.

5. Global events: Global events such as geopolitical tensions, natural disasters, and pandemics can also affect foreign portfolio investments.

Question 26
When Central Bank conducts a sale of securities, the cash reserve of commercial banks shall: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.Increase at slow rate
  • B.Decrease
  • C.Remain constant
  • D.Increase at fast rate
Correct Answer: Decrease

When a central bank conducts a sale of securities, it means that it is selling government securities or bonds to the market participants such as commercial banks, investment banks, or individual investors. In exchange for these securities, the central bank receives cash from the buyers.

 

When commercial banks purchase government securities from the central bank, they pay for these securities by drawing down their reserve accounts with the central bank. A reserve account is an account that commercial banks are required to maintain with the central bank, and it represents the funds that the bank holds in reserve to meet the demands of their depositors.

 

When a bank’s reserve account is reduced as a result of purchasing government securities, its cash reserves decrease. This is because the reserve account is essentially a cash balance that the bank holds with the central bank, and the purchase of securities with this balance means that the cash is transferred out of the bank’s reserve account to the central bank.

 

A reduction in a bank’s cash reserves can impact its ability to lend and create new deposits. Banks use their reserve accounts to meet the cash demands of their depositors, so a decrease in cash reserves could make it more difficult for the bank to meet these demands. As a result, the bank may be more cautious about lending, which could lead to a reduction in the money supply.

Question 27
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)Statement I:Monetary policy on its own cannot influence economic growth but can only supportit by creating congenial factors.Statement II:Monetary policy rates change get transmitted across the markets and eventually get reflected in lending rates, mortgage rates and yields. Hence, monetary policy can address the current inflation.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false.

Statement I is correct as monetary policy alone cannot influence economic growth but can only create favourable conditions that can support growth. Monetary policy can create an environment that is conducive to growth by controlling inflation, stabilizing exchange rates, and ensuring adequate availability of credit.

However, statement II is incorrect as it overstates the effectiveness of monetary policy in addressing inflation. While it is true that changes in monetary policy rates can be transmitted across the markets and reflected in lending rates, mortgage rates, and yields, the impact of monetary policy on inflation is indirect and may not always be immediate or effective. Inflation can be affected by a range of factors, including supply-side constraints, fiscal policy, global factors, and structural factors.

Question 28
Broad money has to be sensitized through:
  • A.CRR
  • B.SLR
  • C.Repo Rate
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

All the options are correct.

 

Broad money includes various forms of money in circulation, including currency, demand deposits, time deposits, and other liquid assets. The factors mentioned in the options can influence the broad money supply:

 

Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR): CRR is the percentage of a bank's total deposits that it must keep as reserves with the central bank. By adjusting the CRR, the central bank can influence the amount of money available for lending and spending in the economy.

 

Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR): SLR is the percentage of a bank's total deposits that it must invest in specified securities, typically government securities. Similar to CRR, adjusting SLR affects the liquidity of banks and, consequently, the broad money supply.

 

Repo Rate: The repo rate is the rate at which the central bank lends money to commercial banks. By changing the repo rate, the central bank can influence the cost of borrowing for banks, impacting their lending activities and, in turn, the broad money supply.

Question 29
Identify the quantitative credit control methods among the following: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)(i) Bank Rate(ii) Credit Rationing(iii) Open Market Operations(iv) Variable Reserve Ratio(v) Selective Credit Control(vi) Liquidity RatioSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (iv) and (v)
  • C.(i), (ii), (v) and (vi)
  • D.(i), (iii), (iv) and (vi)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii), (iv) and (vi)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

In India, the legal framework of RBI's control over the credit structure has been provided Under Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 and the Banking Regulation Act, 1949. Quantitative credit controls are used to maintain proper quantity of credit o money supply in market. Some of the important general credit control methods are:-

 

Bank rate: It is the rate at which the Central bank lends money to the commercial banks for their liquidity requirements. Bank rate is also called discount rate. In other words bank rate is the rate at which the central bank rediscounts eligible papers (like approved securities, bills of exchange, commercial papers etc) held by commercial banks. Bank rate is important because it is the pace setter to other market rates of interest. Bank rates have been changed several times by RBI to control inflation and recession.

 

Open Market Operations: It refers to buying and selling of government securities in open market in order to expand or contract the amount of money in the banking system. This technique is superior to bank rate policy. Purchases inject money into the banking system while sale of securities do the opposite. During last two decades the RBI has been undertaking switch operations. These involve the purchase of one loan against the sale of another or, vice-versa. This policy aims at preventing unrestricted increase in liquidity.

 

Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR): The Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) is an effective instrument of credit control. Under the RBI Act of 1934 every commercial bank has to keep certain minimum cash reserves with RBI. The RBI is empowered to vary the CRR between 3% and 15%. A high CRR reduces the cash for lending and a low CRR increases the cash for lending.

 

Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR): Under Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR), the government has imposed an obligation on the banks to maintain a certain ratio to its total deposits with Bank itself in the form of liquid assets like cash, gold and other securities.

 

Repo and Reserve Repo: In determining interest rate trends, the repo and reverse repo rates are becoming important. Repo means Sale and Repurchase Agreement. Repo is a swap deal involving the immediate Sale of Securities and simultaneous purchase of those securities at a future date, at a predetermined price. Repo rate helps commercial banks to acquire funds from RBI by selling securities and also agreeing to repurchase at a later date.

 

Reverse repo rate is the rate that banks get from RBI for parking their short term excess funds with RBI. Repo and reverse repo operations are used by RBI in its Liquidity Adjustment Facility RBI contracts credit by increasing the repo and reverse repo rates and by decreasing them it expands credit.

Question 30
Which of the following is NOT the main objective of “Fiscal Policy of India”? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.To increase liquidity in economy
  • B.To promote price stability
  • C.To minimize the in-equality in income and wealth
  • D.To promote employment opportunities
Correct Answer: To increase liquidity in economy

Liquidity can be affected through monetary policies and not through the fiscal policies.

Monetary policy refers to central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. By contrast, fiscal policy refers to the government's decisions about taxation and spending. The two sets of policies affect the economy via different mechanisms.

Question 31
In order to control credit and investment, the Central Bank of a country should: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)
  • A.Sell securities in the open market and hike the Cash Reserve Ratio.
  • B.Buy securities from the open market and lower the Cash Reserve Ratio.
  • C.Buy securities from the open market and hike the Cash Reserve Ratio.
  • D.Sell securities in the open market and lower the Cash Reserve Ratio.
Correct Answer: Sell securities in the open market and hike the Cash Reserve Ratio.

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The central bank of a country uses open market operations and changes in reserve requirements (like the Cash Reserve Ratio) to control credit and investment in the economy.

 

Sell securities in the open market: This action reduces the money supply in the economy. When the central bank sells securities, it absorbs money from the banking system, leading to a decrease in the overall money supply.

 

Hike the Cash Reserve Ratio: Increasing the Cash Reserve Ratio requires banks to hold a higher percentage of their deposits in reserve. This reduces the amount of money available for lending, which can have a contractionary effect on credit and investment.

 

Together, selling securities in the open market and hiking the Cash Reserve Ratio are contractionary measures aimed at controlling credit and investment.

Question 32
The Narasimham Committee made separate recommendations for the reforms of _________. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)
  • A.Manufacturing sector
  • B.Banking sector
  • C.Agriculture sector
  • D.Insurance Sector
Correct Answer: Banking sector

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The first Narasimhan Committee was appointed in 1991, and the second one (Committee on Banking Sector Reforms) was appointed in December 1997.Subsequently, the first one widely came to be known as the Narasimham Committee-I (1991) and the second one as Narasimham-II Committee(1998).

 

The purpose of the Narasimham-I Committee was to study all aspects relating to the structure, organisation, functions and procedures of the financial systems and to recommend improvements in their efficiency and productivity. The Committee submitted its report in November 1991.

 

The Narasimham-II Committee was tasked with the progress review of the implementation of the banking reforms since 1992 with the aim of further strengthening the financial institutions of India. It focussed on issues like size of banks and capital adequacy ratio among other things. M. Narasimham, chairman, submitted the report of the Committee on Banking Sector Reforms (Committee-II) in April 1998.

Question 33
Which of the following is not an instrument of monetary policy? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2009)
  • A.Deficit financing
  • B.Statutory Liquidity Ratio
  • C.Cash Reserve Ratio
  • D.Open Market Operations
Correct Answer: Deficit financing

Deficit financing isn't an instrument of monetary policy; instead, it's a fiscal policy tool. Fiscal policy, handled by the government, manages revenue and expenditure to influence the economy's direction. Deficit financing involves the government spending more than it collects in revenue, leading to borrowing to cover the shortfall. Options (B), (C), and (D) represent tools used in monetary policy, such as Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR), Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR), and Open Market Operations (OMO). Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Deficit financing.

Question 34
Read the given passage and answer the questions that follow.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)The Monetary Policy Committee of the RBI should neither raise policy rates nor wind up its accommodative policy stance. Yes, inflation has been on the rise, and growth has been setting in.This is the time to consolidate growth not to be spooked by transient, supply-constrained inflation. Choking off supply-side price shocks is self-defeating. Higher prices will curb demand and stimulate additional supplies, if the prices are allowed to work their way through the system, instead of being choked off through demand suppression. It is only the second-order effect of price shocks in energy, logistics and labour that call for curtailment of demand via higher interest rates.Far from there being any sign of excess demand, the latest available national income figures suggest squeezed consumption and constrained investment. GDP this fiscal would struggle to recover the size attained at the end of 2019-20. The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would bewholly unsuited for inflation caused by supply disruptions and a spike in energy prices. The right way to combat elevated inflation right now is to reduce the burden of taxes that energy bears in India. Both the Centre and the states should share the tax-cuts. They should take this action, even as they strive to find common ground on bringing energy under the goods and services tax. The government also has the cushion of relatively high import duties that can be pared, to lower prices. Stepping up production to increase supplies is another part of supply-constrained inflation.There are measures the RBI can take to increase access to credit by micro, small and medium enterprises, other than enhancing liquidity in general in the hope that some would find its way to the small sector. The RBI can do its bit to realise the government mandate for all large companies to purchase their inputs from the Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS), for example, if that improves trade finance significantly, some reduction in liquidity would not matter.Which one of the following measures the RBI can take to consolidate growth?
  • A.Reduce tax on fuel price
  • B.Reduce import duty
  • C.Increase access to credit by MSMEs
  • D.Absorb price increase by providing subsidies
Correct Answer: Increase access to credit by MSMEs

The answer is derived from the lines “There are measures the RBI can take to increase access to credit by micro, small and medium enterprises, other than enhancing liquidity in general in the hope that some would find its way to the small sector.”

Question 35
Read the given passage and answer the questions that follow (91-95). (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)The Monetary Policy Committee of the RBI should neither raise policy rates nor wind up its accommodative policy stance. Yes, inflation has been on the rise, and growth has been setting in.This is the time to consolidate growth not to be spooked by transient, supply-constrained inflation. Choking off supply-side price shocks is self-defeating. Higher prices will curb demand and stimulate additional supplies, if the prices are allowed to work their way through the system, instead of being choked off through demand suppression. It is only the second-order effect of price shocks in energy, logistics and labour that call for curtailment of demand via higher interest rates.Far from there being any sign of excess demand, the latest available national income figures suggest squeezed consumption and constrained investment. GDP this fiscal would struggle to recover the size attained at the end of 2019-20. The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would be wholly unsuited for inflationcaused by supply disruptions and a spike in energy prices. The right way to combat elevated inflation right now is to reduce the burden of taxes that energy bears in India. Both the Centre and the states should share the tax-cuts. They should take this action, even as they strive to find common ground on bringing energy under the goods and services tax. The government also has the cushion of relatively high import duties that can be pared, to lower prices. Stepping up production to increase supplies is another part of supply-constrained inflation.There are measures the RBI can take to increase access to credit by micro, small and medium enterprises, other than enhancing liquidity in general in the hope that some would find its way to the small sector.   • A.Reduce interest rate
  • B.Increase interest rate
  • C.Suppression of demand
  • D.Stimulate additional supply
Correct Answer: Stimulate additional supply

The answer is derived from the lines “Yes, inflation has been on the rise and growth has been setting. This is the time to consolidate growth not to be spooked by transient, supply- constrained inflation. Choking off supply-side price shocks is self-defeating. Higher prices will curb demand and stimulate additional supplies, if the prices are allowed to work their way through the system, instead of being choked off through demand suppression. It is only the second-order effect of price shocks in energy, logistics and labour that call for curtailment of demand via higher interest rates.”

Question 36
Read the given passage and answer the questions that follow (91-95).(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)The Monetary Policy Committee of the RBI should neither raise policy rates nor wind up its accommodative policy stance. Yes, inflation has been on the rise, and growth has been setting in.This is the time to consolidate growth not to be spooked by transient, supply-constrained inflation. Choking off supply-side price shocks is self-defeating. Higher prices will curb demand and stimulate additional supplies, if the prices are allowed to work their way through the system, instead of being choked off through demand suppression. It is only the second-order effect of price shocks in energy, logistics and labour that call for curtailment of demand via higher interest rates.Far from there being any sign of excess demand, the latest available national income figures suggest squeezed consumption and constrained investment. GDP this fiscal would struggle to recover the size attained at the end of 2019-20. The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would bewholly unsuited for inflation caused by supply disruptions and a spike in energy prices. They should take this action, even as they strive to find common ground on bringing energy under the goods and services tax.   • A.Both the Centre and the States should share the tax cuts equally
  • B.GOP this fiscal would find it difficult to recover the size attained at the end of 2019-20
  • C.Curtailment of demand via higher interest rates can be used in a limited way
  • D.Choking off supply-side price shocks will affect growth adversely
Correct Answer: Both the Centre and the States should share the tax cuts equally

According to the passage, statement A is not true.

Question 37
Read the given passage and answer the questions that follow (91-95). Choking off supply-side price shocks is self-defeating. Higher prices will curb demand and stimulate additional supplies, if the prices are allowed to work their way through the system, instead of being choked off through demand suppression. It is only the second-order effect of price shocks in energy, logistics and labour that call for curtailment of demand via higher interest rates.Far from there being any sign of excess demand, the latest available national income figures suggest squeezed consumption and constrained investment. GDP this fiscal would struggle to recover the size attained at the end of 2019-20. The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would be wholly unsuited for inflationcaused by supply disruptions and a spike in energy prices.   • C.Supply disruptions
  • D.Increase in demand

Question 38
Read the given passage and answer the questions that follow (91-95). (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)The Monetary Policy Committee of the RBI should neither raise policy rates nor wind up its accommodative policy stance. Yes, inflation has been on the rise, and growth has been setting in.This is the time to consolidate growth not to be spooked by transient, supply-constrained inflation. Choking off supply-side price shocks is self-defeating. Higher prices will curb demand and stimulate additional supplies, if the prices are allowed to work their way through the system, instead of being choked off through demand suppression. It is only the second-order effect of price shocks in energy, logistics and labour that call for curtailment of demand via higher interest rates.Far from there being any sign of excess demand, the latest available national income figures suggest squeezed consumption and constrained investment. GDP this fiscal would struggle to recover the size attained at the end of 2019-20. The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would be wholly unsuited for inflationcaused by supply disruptions and a spike in energy prices. The right way to combat elevated inflation right now is to reduce the burden of taxes that energy bears in India. Both the Centre and the states should share the tax-cuts. They should take this action, even as they strive to find common ground on bringing energy under the goods and services tax. The government also has the cushion of relatively high import duties that can be pared, to lower prices. Stepping up production to increase supplies is another part of supply-constrained inflation.There are measures the RBI can take to increase access to credit by micro, small and medium enterprises, other than enhancing liquidity in general in the hope that some would find its way to the small sector. TheRBI can do its bit to realise the government mandate for all large companies to purchase their inputs from the Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS), for example, if that improves trade finance significantly, some reduction in liquidity would not matter.Given below are two statements. One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled asReason RAssertion ‘A’:The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would be wholly suited for inflation caused by a spike in energy prices.Reason ‘R’:The right way to combat elevated inflation right now is to reduce the burden of taxes that energy bears in India.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct
Correct Answer: A is not correct but R is correct

A is not correct but R is correct.

 

The answer is derived from the lines “The policy response appropriate for inflation caused by excess demand would be wholly unsuited for inflation caused by supply disruptions and a spike in energy prices. The right way to combat elevated inflation right now is to reduce the burden of taxes that energy bears in India. Both the Centre and the states should share the tax cuts.”

Question 39
The central bank can significantly influence the savings, investments and consumer spending in the economy through which of the following policy? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Fiscal Policy
  • B.Monetary Policy
  • C.Industrial Policy
  • D.Foreign Exchange Policy
Correct Answer: Monetary Policy

Option B is the correct answer. Monetary policy, conducted by the central bank, involves managing the money supply and interest rates to influence savings, investments, and consumer spending in an economy. It's used to regulate economic growth, inflation, and employment by altering the money supply and interest rates.

Question 40
Why do Central banks intervene to affect exchange rates? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) To influence domestic production.(b) To influence trade flows.(c) To influence domestic interest rates.(d) To inject liquidity in domestic markets.(e) To smoothen fluctuations in exchange rates.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

(a) To influence domestic production: Central banks may intervene in exchange rates to influence the competitiveness of domestic producers. A weaker currency can make exports more competitive, potentially boosting domestic production.

 

(b) To influence trade flows: Exchange rate interventions can impact the trade balance by making exports more competitive (with a weaker currency) or imports more expensive (with a stronger currency).

 

(e) To smoothen fluctuations in exchange rates: Central banks may intervene to prevent excessive volatility or abrupt movements in exchange rates, contributing to stability in the foreign exchange market.

Question 41
Why do Central banks intervene to affect exchange rates? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) To influence domestic production.(b) To influence trade flows.(c) To influence domestic interest rates.(d) To inject liquidity in domestic markets.(e) To smoothen fluctuations in exchange rates.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

(a) To influence domestic production: Central banks may intervene in exchange rates to influence the competitiveness of domestic producers. A weaker currency can make exports more competitive, potentially boosting domestic production.

 

(b) To influence trade flows: Exchange rate interventions can impact the trade balance by making exports more competitive (with a weaker currency) or imports more expensive (with a stronger currency).

 

(e) To smoothen fluctuations in exchange rates: Central banks may intervene to prevent excessive volatility or abrupt movements in exchange rates, contributing to stability in the foreign exchange market.

Question 42
Match the items of List –I with the List – II and indicate the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)List – Ia. Fiscal Policyb. Technology Policyc. Macro-Economic Policyd. Monetary PolicyList – IIi. Mitigation of National hazardsii. Balance of Paymentiii. Fiscal Federalismiv. InflationSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-i b-ii c-iii d-iv
  • B.a-iii b-i c-ii d-iv
  • C.a-iv b-iii c-i d-ii
  • D.a-ii b-i c-iv d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii b-i c-ii d-iv

The correct match for the items in List - I with List - II is (B) a-iii b-i c-ii d-iv.

 

a. Fiscal Policy matches with iii. Fiscal Federalism because fiscal policy refers to the government's use of taxation and government spending to influence the economy. Fiscal federalism, on the other hand, deals with the distribution of resources and responsibilities between the central government and sub-national entities (like states or provinces). Fiscal policy often plays a crucial role in fiscal federalism, as it determines how resources are allocated between different levels of government.

 

b. Technology Policy matches with i. Mitigation of National hazards because technology policies can be instrumental in mitigating national hazards or disasters. For example, advanced technology and early warning systems can help in predicting and responding to natural disasters more effectively.

 

c. Macro-Economic Policy matches with ii. Balance of Payment because macroeconomic policies, such as fiscal and monetary policies, can have a significant impact on a country's balance of payments. The balance of payments reflects a country's economic transactions with the rest of the world, and macroeconomic policies can influence factors like exchange rates and trade balances, which are components of the balance of payments.

 

d. Monetary Policy matches with iv. Inflation because monetary policy is often used by central banks to control inflation. Central banks adjust interest rates and the money supply to manage inflationary pressures in the economy. Inflation refers to the increase in the general price level of goods and services over time, and monetary policy plays a key role in controlling it.

Question 43
Match List-I withList-II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)List-I(a) Fiscal, Monetary and Industrial Policies(b) Social obligations towards several stakeholders(c) Consumers, shareholders, Suppliers, creditors etc.(d) Moral principles that defines the right or wrongList-II(i) Social responsibilities(ii) Stakeholders/interest group(iii) Business ethics(iv) Economic policiesChoose the correct option from those given below:
  • A.(a)-(iii);(b)-(i);(c)-(iv);(d)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(i);(b)-(ii);(c)-(iv);(d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(ii);(b)-(iv);(c)-(iii);(d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(iv);(b)-(i);(c)-(ii);(d)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iv);(b)-(i);(c)-(ii);(d)-(iii)

So, the correct option is (D) (a)-(iv); (b)-(i); (c)-(ii); (d)-(iii)

 

(a) Fiscal, monetary, and Industrial policies (List-I) matches with (iv) Economic policies (List-II): This match is accurate because fiscal, monetary, and industrial policies are all types of economic policies. These policies are formulated to regulate economic activities, including fiscal (government spending and taxation), monetary (management of money supply and interest rates), and industrial (related to industrial development).

 

(b) Social obligations towards several stakeholders (List-I) matches with (i) Social responsibilities (List-II): This match is correct because social obligations often encompass responsibilities towards several stakeholders. Businesses and organizations have social responsibilities to various groups in society, such as employees, communities, and customers.

 

(c) Consumers, shareholders, Suppliers, creditors, etc. (List-I) matches with (ii) Stakeholders/ interest group (List-II): This match is accurate because consumers, shareholders, suppliers, creditors, etc., are all examples of stakeholders or interest groups in the context of business. These groups have a vested interest in the activities and decisions of businesses.

 

(d) Moral principles that define the right or wrong (List-I) matches with (iii) Business ethics (List-II): This match is correct because moral principles form the foundation of business ethics. Business ethics is concerned with determining what is considered right or wrong in business practices. Moral principles guide ethical decision-making within the business context.

Question 44
Which one is NOT the main objective of fiscal policy of India?
  • A.To increase liquidity in the economy.
  • B.To promote price stability
  • C.To minimize the inequalities of income and wealth
  • D.To promote employment opportunities.
Correct Answer: To increase liquidity in the economy.

Option A is incorrect. Liquidity can be increased through monetary policy and not fiscal policy.

 

Fiscal Policy refers to the governing bodies spending and taxation to influence the economic conditions, mainly the macroeconomic condition. It includes employment, inflation, aggregate demand for goods and services and economic growth.

Question 45
Difference between the government’s total expenditure and its total receipts excluding borrowing is referred to as:
  • A.Primary Deficit
  • B.Fiscal Deficit
  • C.Budget Deficit
  • D.Revenue Deficit
Correct Answer: Fiscal Deficit

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Fiscal Deficit is the difference between total revenue and total expenditure of the government is termed as fiscal deficit. It is an indication of the total borrowings needed by the government. While calculating the total revenue, borrowings are not included.

Question 46
Quantitative measures like SLR, CRR and Qualitative measures like Direct Action, Rationing of credit comes under which type of policies of the government?
  • A.Foreign Trade Policy
  • B.Industrial Policy
  • C.Monetary Policy
  • D.Fiscal Policy
Correct Answer: Monetary Policy

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Quantitative measures like Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) and Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) and qualitative measures like Direct Action and rationing of credit are tools of monetary policy.

Question 47
The _________ is a condition of slow economic growth and relatively high unemployment, or economic stagnation, accompanied by rising prices.
  • A.Stagflation
  • B.Deflation
  • C.Recession
  • D.Inflation
Correct Answer: Stagflation

Stagflation is a condition characterized by slow economic growth, high unemployment, and rising prices (inflation) occurring simultaneously. It is a unique and challenging economic situation because inflation and unemployment are typically inversely related in standard economic models. In typical economic circumstances, high inflation might be associated with low unemployment (and vice versa).

Question 48
Match the items in Column-I to the items in Column-II:Column – Ia. Fiscal deficitb. SEBIc. RBId. National IncomeColumn – IIi. Market Securitiesii. Government expenditureiii. Economic growthiv. Monetary policySelect the correct answer usingthe codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-I, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-I, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • D.a-I, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-I, c-iv, d-ii

Fiscal Deficit is essentially the difference between what government spends and what it earns. Therefore, there is a fear that high fiscal imbalance will negatively affect the economic growth of the country. There are controversial thoughts on the relationship between fiscal deficit and economic growth. There are three major strands of arguments regarding the effectiveness of fiscal policy on growth i.e. The Neoclassical view, Keynesian view and Ricardian Equivalence view.

 

The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is a regulatory body of the Government of India. It controls the securities market. It was established on 12th April 1992 under the SEBI Act, 1992. It is headquartered in Mumbai, India. It has regional offices in major cities of India such as New Delhi, Kolkata, Chennai and Ahmadabad.

 

The Monetary policy refers to the policy of the central bank – i.e., Reserve Bank of India – in matters of interest rates, money supply and availability of credit. It is through the monetary policy, RBI controls inflation in the country. RBI uses various monetary policy instruments like REPO rate, Reverse RERO rate, SLR, CRR etc. to achieve its purpose.

 

Government spending or expenditure includes all government consumption, investment, and transfer payments. In National Income accounting the acquisition by governments of goods and services for current use, to directly satisfy the individual or collective needs of the community, is classed as government final consumption expenditure. Government acquisition of goods and services intended to create future benefits, such as infrastructure investment or research spending, is classed as government investment (government gross capital formation). These 2 types of government spending, on final consumption and on gross capital formation, together constitute one of the major components of Gross Domestic Product.

Quiz Attempt #118898

Total Questions: 54
Question 1
Which is the legal framework governing the Regional Rural Banks (RRBs)?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)a) Regional Rural Banks Act, 1976b) Regional Rural Banks Act, 1966c) Small Industries Development Bank of India, 1989d) Banking Regulation Act, 1949e) Indian Partnership Act, 1932Choose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a and d only
  • B.b and d only
  • C.a and c only
  • D.b and e only
Correct Answer: a and d only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Regional Rural Banks were established under the provisions of an Ordinance passed on in September 1975 and the Regional Rural Bank Act 1976 to provide sufficient banking and credit facility for agriculture and other rural sectors. Regional Rural Banks (RRB) are Indian Scheduled Commercial Banks (Government Banks) operating at regional level in different states of India. They have been created with a view of serving primarily the rural areas of India with basic banking and financial services. However, RRBs may have branches set up for urban operations and their area of operation may include urban area too.

 

These banks are governed by RRB Act 1976 and Banking Regulation Act 1949.

 

The area of operation of RRBs is limited to the area as notified by Government of India covering one or more districts in the State. RRBs perform various functions in following heads:

  • Providing banking facilities to rural and semi –urban areas.
  • Carrying out government operations like disbursement of wages of MGNREGA workers, distribution of pension etc.

Providing Para-Banking facilities like locker facilities, debit and credit cards, mobile banking, internet banking, UPI etc.

Question 2
Which are the correct regulatory provisions for foreign bank operation in India?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)A. They are incorporated in India and have their head office in foreign countryB. Foreign banks since 2002 have been allowed to set up their subsidiaries in IndiaC. The foreign banks are allowed to operate in India even if they are not financially soundD. Theyhave tooperate according to the banking regulation in IndiaE. RBI approved that foreign banks which are present in India could open their branchesChoose the correct answer the which are present in India could open their branches
  • A.A, C, E only
  • B.E, B, C only
  • C.B, D, E only
  • D.C, D, E only
Correct Answer: B, D, E only

The correct answer is (C) B, D, E only

 

Option B is correct as foreign banks have been allowed to set up subsidiaries in India since 2002.

Option D is correct as foreign banks operating in India must adhere to banking regulations set by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).

Option E is correct as the RBI approves the opening of branches by foreign banks present in India.

Question 3
Arrange the following SBI-sponsored RRBs in an increasing order of their existence since formation.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Rajasthan Marudhara Gramin Bankb. Telangana Gramin Bankc. Saurashtra Gramin Bankd. Madhyanchal Gramin Banke. Arunachal Pradesh Rural BankChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A, D, B, E, C
  • B.C, E, D, A, B
  • C.B, A, C, E, D
  • D.D, E, A, B, C
Correct Answer: C, E, D, A, B

The correct answer is option B.

  • Saurashtra Gramin Bank – 1978
  • Arunachal Pradesh Rural Bank – 1983
  • Madhyanchal Gramin Bank – 2012
  • Rajasthan Marudhara Gramin Bank – 2014 (April)
  • Telangana Gramin Bank – 2014 (October)
Question 4
In which one of the following ratios, the share capital of RRBs is prescribed for the Central Government, State Government and Sponsoring bank?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.50:30:20
