In the event that the buyer is unable to make payment on the purchase, the bank will be required to cover the full or remaining amount of the purchase. Due to the nature of international dealings, including factors such as distance, differing laws in each country, and difficulty in knowing each party personally, the use of letters of credit has become a very important aspect of international trade.

 

A Bank Reference is a bank manager’s written opinion of their customer’s credit standing. Bank references predate Credit Reports and were once the only way of checking out the Creditworthiness of a consumer. They remain a valid way to check an individual’s credit standing, but they are less detailed than a credit report.

 

If some business firm in India wants to import certain goods, first of all, it has to gather information about such suppliers who can supply the required goods. Such information can be gathered through trade directions, trade associations, and organizations. After identifying the countries and firms, a trader has to send a trade enquiry for collecting information about their export prices, policies and terms of exports.

 

A credit bureau is an agency that collects and researches individual credit information and sells it for a fee to creditors so they can make a decision on granting loans.

Question 31
In India, NIFTY and SENSEX are calculated on the basis of: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.Market capitalisation
  • B.Paid up capital
  • C.Free-float market capitalisation
  • D.Authorized share capital
Correct Answer: Free-float market capitalisation

In free float market capitalisation, the value of the company is calculated by excluding shares held by the promoters. These excluded shares are the free float shares. For example if a company has issued 10 lakh shares of face value Rs 10, but of these, four lakh shares is owned by the promoter, then the free float market capitalisation is Rs 60 lakh.

 

Market capitalisation is the outstanding number of shares of a company multiplied by its current market price. For example, if a company has 1 lakh outstanding shares and the stock price is Rs 20, then the market capitalization of the company is Rs 20 lakh.

Question 32
Financial Instruments which are issued with detachable warrants and are redeemable after certain period is known as:
  • A.Deep Discount Bonds
  • B.Secured Premium Notes
  • C.Bunny Bonds
  • D.Junk Bonds
Correct Answer: Secured Premium Notes

Secured Premium Note is a kind of non-convertible debenture (NCD) attached with warrant (i.e. option). SpN is a hybrid security i.e. it combines both features of equity and debt products. SpN can be only issued by the listed companies after having approval from the Central Government.

Features of a SpN:

a) SpN instruments are issued with a detachable warrant.

b) These instruments have lock-in-period for 4 to 7 years. No interest is paid during the lock in period.

c) The detachable warrants are convertible into equity shares provided the SpNs are fully paid. The conversion of detachable warrants into equity has to be done within the specified time.

d) After the lock-in-period, the holder has an option to sell back the SpN to the company at par value. If the holder exercises this option, no interest/premium is paid on redemption.

e) In case the holder keeps his investment further, he is repaid the principal amount along with the additional interest/premium on redemption in installments.

f) SpN were so formulated that the return on investment was treated as capital gain and not regular income. Consequently, the rate of tax applicable was lower.

 

A bond that sells at a significant discount from par value is known as Deep Discount Bond. Example: IDBI & SIDBI had issued this instrument. For a deep discount price of Rs.5,300 in IDBI the investor got a bond with the face value of ` 2,00,000. Deep discount bonds appreciate to its face value over the maturity period. Alternatively, the investor can withdraw from the investment periodically after 5 years. The capital appreciation is charged to tax at capital gains rate which is lower than normal income tax rate.

 

A bunny bond is a type of bond that offers investors the option to reinvest coupon payments into additional bonds with the same coupon and maturity. This type of bond is also known as multiplier bond or guaranteed coupon reinvestment bond.

 

A junk bond is a fixed-income instrument that refers to a high-yield or noninvestment-grade bond. Junk bonds carry a credit rating of BB or lower by Standard & Poor's (S&P), or Ba or below by Moody's Investors Service. Junk bonds are so called because of their higher default risk in relation to investment-grade bonds.

Question 33
Following statements are related to futures contracts. Choose the statements that are not true:(a) Purchase of a futures contract is called short position.(b) Currency futures are traded on an exchange in standardized form and in fixed quantity.(c) Default risk in futures contract is high compared to forward contract.Codes:
  • A.only (a) and (b)
  • B.only (a) and (c)
  • C.(a), (b) and (c)
  • D.only (b)
Correct Answer: only (a) and (c)

A futures contract is a legal agreement to buy or sell a particular commodity or asset at a predetermined price at a specified time in the future. Futures contracts are standardized for quality and quantity to facilitate trading on a futures exchange. The buyer of a futures contract is taking on the obligation to buy the underlying asset when the futures contract expires.

 

The seller of the futures contract is taking on the obligation to provide the underlying asset at the expiration date.

1. Futures contracts are traded on an exchange while forward contracts are privately traded.

2. Since they are traded on exchange, futures contracts are highly standardized. Forward contracts, on the other hand, are customized as per the requirements of the counterparties.

3. A single clearinghouse acts as the counterparty for all futures contracts. This means that the clearinghouse is the buyer for every seller and seller for every buyer. This eliminates the risk of default, and also allows traders to reverse their positions at a future date.

4. Futures contracts require a margin to be posted at the contract initiation, which fluctuates as the futures prices fluctuate. There is no such margin requirement in a forward contract.

5. The government regulates futures market while the forward market is not regulated.

Question 34
Match the items of Column – I with the items in Column – II and suggest the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016) (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)List – Ia. Interbank call marketb. Commercial Billsc. Commercial paper marketd. Treasury billsList – IIi. Money marketii. Promissory noteiii. Short-term maturityiv. Government papersSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • C.a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv

An interbank call market is a short-term money market which allows for large financial institutions, such as banks, mutual funds and corporations, to borrow and lend money at interbank rates. The loans in the call money market are very short, usually lasting no longer than a week and are often used to help banks meet reserve requirements.

 

Commercial bills market: The commercial bills are issued by the seller (drawer) on the buyer (drawee) for the value of goods delivered by him. These bills are of 30 days, 60 days or 90 days maturity. If the seller is in need of funds, he may draw a bill and send it to the buyer for seller is in need of funds, he may draw a bill and send it to the buyer for acceptance. The buyer accepts the bill and promises to make payment on the due date. He may also approach his bank to accept the bill.

 

Treasury Bills (T-Bills) – Treasury bills were first issued by the Indian government in 1917. Treasury bills are short­ term financial instruments that are issued by the Central Bank of the country. It is one of the safest money market instruments as it is void of market risks, though the return on investments is not that huge. Treasury bills are circulated by the primary as well as the secondary markets. The maturity periods for treasury bills are respectively 3­month, 6­ month and 1­year. The price with which treasury bills are issued comes separate from that of the face value, and the face value is achieved upon maturity. On maturity, one gets the interest on the buy value as well. To be specific, the buy value is determined by a bidding process, that too in auctions.

 

Commercial paper market: Commercial paper refers to unsecured promissory notes issued by credit worthy companies to borrow funds on a short­ term basis. They are transferable by endorsement and delivery. Maturity period of commercial paper lies between 7 days and 365 days.

Question 35
Identify the incorrect statement(s), regarding money market, among the following: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)(a) The call money market deals in short term finance repayable on demand, with a maturity period varying from one day to 14 days.(b) Treasury bills are instruments of short-term borrowing by the Government of India, issued as promissory notes under discount.(c) A reduction in the repo rate helps banks to get money at a cheaper rate.(d) Money market mutual funds invest money in specifically, high-quality and very short maturity-based money market instruments.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes :
  • A.(a) and (c)
  • B.(a), (b) and (c)
  • C.(d)
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

The call money market deals in short term finance repayable on demand, with a maturity period varying from one day to 14 days.

Treasury bills are instruments of short-term borrowing by the Government of India, issued as promissory notes under discount.

A reduction in the repo rate helps banks to get money at a cheaper rate.

Money market mutual funds invest money in specifically, high-quality and very short maturity-based money market instruments.

Quiz Attempt #118904

Total Questions: 31
Question 1
Choose incorrect statement from the following: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.28 Days T-bills were introduced in 1998
  • B.364 Days T-bills were introduced in 1992
  • C.182 Days T-bills were introduced in 1986
  • D.273 Days T-bills were introduced in 2006
Correct Answer: 273 Days T-bills were introduced in 2006

Option D is incorrect statement.

 

Treasury bills or T-bills, which are money market instruments, are short term debt instruments issued by the Government of India and are presently issued in three tenors, namely, 91 day, 182 day and 364 day. Treasury bills are zero coupon securities and pay no interest. Instead, they are issued at a discount and redeemed at the face value at maturity. For example, a 91 day Treasury bill of ₹100/- (face value) may be issued at say ₹ 98.20, that is, at a discount of say, ₹1.80 and would be redeemed at the face value of ₹100/-. The return to the investors is the difference between the maturity value or the face value (that is ₹100) and the issue price (for calculation of yield on Treasury Bills).

 

Information regarding various T-bills is given below:

 

Question 2
Match the items of List – I with those of the List – II and choose the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)List – Ia. Process of admitting securities for trading on a recognized stock exchangeb. Device adopted to make profit out of the difference in prices of a security in two markets.c. The facility to carry forward a transaction from one settlement period to anotherd. An independent broker who deals in securities on his own behalfList – IIi. Jobberii. Badla Transactioniii. Listingiv. ArbitrageCodes:
  • A.a-iii, b-iv, c-I, d-ii
  • B.a-iii. b-iv, c-ii. d-i
  • C.a-ii, b-I, c-iv, d-iii
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-I, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii. b-iv, c-ii. d-i

Jobbers: Jobbers are also members of the stock exchange who do business only for themselves. Jobbers as members of the stock exchange, deal in shares and debentures as independent operators. A jobber is a market maker who gives two­way quotes for security at any point of time, a lower quotation for buying and a higher quotation for selling of securities. The difference between the two prices is termed as jobber's profit. Jobbers cannot deal on behalf of public and are barred from taking commission. In India, there is no clear­cut distinction between jobbers and brokers. Here, a member can act as both a broker and a jobber at the same time.

 

Badla was an indigenous carry-forward system invented on the Bombay Stock Exchange as a solution to the perpetual lack of liquidity in the secondary market. Badla were banned by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) in 1993, effective March 1994, amid complaints from foreign investors, with the expectation that it would be replaced by a futures-and-options exchange. Such an exchange was not established and badla were legalized again in 1996 (with a carry-forward limit of Rs 200 million per broker) and banned again on 2 July 2001, following the introduction of futures contracts in 2000.

 

Listing Requirement: While only those securities can be dealt within the secondary market, which have been approved for the purpose (listed), there is no such requirement in case of primary market.

 

Arbitrage: Arbitrage is the simultaneous purchase and sale of an asset to profit from an imbalance in the price. It is a trade that profits by exploiting the price differences of identical or similar financial instruments on different markets or in different forms. Arbitrage exists as a result of market inefficiencies and would therefore not exist if all markets were perfectly efficient.

Question 3
Which of the following are the components of capital market? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)I. Government Securities MarketII. Commercial Bill MarketIII. Industrial Securities MarketIV. Treasury Bill MarketV. Long-term Loans MarketCodes:
  • A.I, III, IV, V
  • B.I, II, III
  • C.I, III, V
  • D.I, II, III, IV, V
Correct Answer: I, III, V

The capital market is a market for financial assets which have a long or indefinite maturity. Generally, it deals with long term securities which have a maturity period of more than 1 year. It has low liquidity. The Capital market instruments include stocks, shares, debentures, bonds, corporate deposits etc. Capital market may be further divided into 3 types namely:

1. Industrial Securities Market

2. Government Securities Market

3. Long-term Loans Market.

 

1. Industrial Securities Market

The Industrial Securities Market refers to market for those financial instruments/claims/obligations that are commonly and readily transferable by sale. As the very name implies, it is a market for industrial securities, namely: (i) Equity shares, (ii) Preference shares and (iii) Debentures or Bonds. It is a market where industrial concerns raise their capital or debt by issuing appropriate instruments. It can be further subdivided into 2 types. They are (i) Primary market and (ii) Secondary market.

 

2. Government Securities Market

It is also called Gilt-Edged Securities Market. It is a market where government securities are traded. In India, there are many kinds of Government securities – short term and long term. Long-term securities are traded in this market while short term securities are traded in money market. The secondary market for these securities is very narrow since most of the institutional investors tend to retain these securities until maturity.

 

3. Long-term Loans Market

Development banks and commercial banks play a significant role in this market by supplying long term loans to corporate customers. Long term loans market may further be classified into – (i) Term loans, (ii) Mortgages and (iii) Financial Guarantees markets.

Question 4
Rematerialization of securities is meant by
  • A.Repossession of securities
  • B.Reholding in Physical form
  • C.Repurchase of securities
  • D.Restoring the lost right
Correct Answer: Reholding in Physical form

Rematerialisation is the process by which a client can get his electronic holdings converted into physical certificates. The client has to submit the rematerialisation request to the Depository Participant (DP) with whom he has an account. The DP enters the request in its system which blocks the client's holdings to that extent automatically. The DP releases the request to NSDL and sends the request form to the Issuer/ R&T agent. The Issuer/ R&T agent then prints the certificates, despatches the same to the client and simultaneously electronically confirms the acceptance of the request to NSDL. Thereafter, the client's blocked balances are debited.

Question 5
What is a future contract?(a) It is an agreement to buy or to sell a specified quantity of asset during a given period at a spot price.(b) It is a marketable obligation to buy or to sell a specified quantity of a particular asset during a period at a given price.(c) It is an option to buy or to sell a specified quantity of asset during a given period for a given price.(d) It is a marketable obligation to buy or sell a specified quantity of particular assets during a given period of time at a price to be determined in future.Codes:
  • A.(a) and (c)
  • B.(c) and (d)
  • C.(b) only
  • D.(a) and (d)
Correct Answer: (b) only

A futures contract may be defined as a contractual obligation in terms of which one party to the deal undertakes on T+0 to sell an asset at a price (determined on T+0) on a future date, and the other party undertakes to buy the same asset at the same price on the same future date.

 

Features of Futures Contract are given below:

(i) Exchange Traded: Unlike forward contracts, which are OTC product, futures are traded on organized future exchanges. Continuous trading provides liquidity to future contracts holders and also significantly helps in price discovery process.

(ii) Standardization with respect to Price, Quality, Contract Size and Delivery date

(iii) Mark to Market (MTM): Daily MTM to avoid credit risk

(iv) Initial Margin: It is essential to avoid default in daily MTM. Both buyer and seller keep initial margin

(v) Novation: Exchange becomes the counter-party all transactions and buyers and sellers they do not know each other. It avoid the credit risk.

(vi) Clearing House: The clearing House is the principal institution in a future market. All settlements take

place through the clearing house.

(vii) Delivery is Rare: In futures market, actual delivery is rare or hardly one percent of all contracts traded. This indicates, futures market is used for hedging device against price risk and may be for speculative purpose.

(viii) Anonymous Trading: Buyer does not know the seller and vice-a-versa. Only exchange knows about the buyers and sellers for Margin and MTM and any other legal purposes.

(ix) Easy Exit: Investors can exit from the future contract anytime by going to exchange traded market and selling it to the exchange and cancel the transaction.

Question 6
Identify the incorrect statement from the following:
  • A.Broken-date contract is a full-month forward contract.
  • B.Currency arbitrage refers to making profit by buying a currency cheap in one market and selling it dear in the other market at a particular point of time.
  • C.Currency Futures Market refers to organized foreign exchange market where a fixed amount of a currency is exchanged on a fixed maturity date in the pit.
  • D.Currency Options Market refers to market for the exchange of currency where the option buyer enjoys the privilege of not exercising the option if the rate is not favourable
Correct Answer: Broken-date contract is a full-month forward contract.

A trading date in a forward or money market contract that is outside the standard maturity date is known as broken date. Standard periods are one week, two weeks, one month, six months etc. For example, a normal 2-month contract would be from June 15 to August 15. Maturity on August 10 would be considered a broken date. It is also known as odd date.

Question 7
Match the items of List - I with List - II and denote the code of correct matching:List - I(a) Future(b) Swap(c) Hedging(d) ForwardList - II(i) Consists of purchase or sale of commodities in two different markets with the expectations that a future change in price in one market will be offset by an opposite change in the other market(ii) A contract in which a seller agrees to deliver an asset to a buyer at a predetermined price at some future date as privately negotiated(iii) A contractual agreement for exchanging a steam of payments with opposite and matching needs, to reap the benefit arising due to market discrepancies(iv) A contract covering the purchase and sale of physical commodities or financial instruments for future delivery on a future exchange floor.Code:
  • A.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)

Future- A futures contract is a legal agreement to buy or sell a particular commodity or asset at a predetermined price at a specified time in the future. Futures contracts are standardized for quality and quantity to facilitate trading on a futures exchange. The buyer of a futures contract is taking on the obligation to buy the underlying asset when the futures contract expires. The seller of the futures contract is taking on the obligation to provide the underlying asset at the expiration date. 

 

Swap- A swap is a derivative contract through which two parties exchange the cash flows or liabilities from two different financial instruments. Most swaps involve cash flows based on a notional principal amount such as a loan or bond, although the instrument can be almost anything. Usually, the principal does not change hands. Each cash flow comprises one leg of the swap. One cash flow is generally fixed, while the other is variable and based on a benchmark interest rate, floating currency exchange rate or index price.

 

Hedging- Hedging is the simultaneous purchase and sale of two assets in the expectation of a gain from different subsequent movements in the price of those assets. Usually the two assets are equivalent in all respects except maturity.

 

Forward Contract- A forward contract is a private agreement between two parties giving the buyer an obligation into purchase an asset (and the seller an obligation to sell an asset) at a set price at a future point in time. The assets often traded in forward contracts include commodities like grain, precious metals, electricity, oil, beef, orange juice, and natural gas, but foreign currencies and financial instruments are also part of today's forward markets.

Question 8
What is the popular term used for that type of option in Foreign Exchange Market which provides the holder the right to purchase or sell foreign currency at the most favorable exchange rate realized over the life of the option?
  • A.Forward reversing option
  • B.Preference option
  • C.Look back option
  • D.Basket option
Correct Answer: Look back option

As a type of exotic option, the Lookback option allows the user to "look back," or review, the prices of an underlying asset over the lifespan of the option after it has been purchased. The holder may then exercise the option based on the most beneficial price of the underlying asset. The holder can take advantage of the widest differential between the strike price and the price of the underlying asset. Lookback options do not trade on major exchanges. Instead, they are unlisted and trade over-the-counter (OTC).

 

Forward reversing option- An exotic option in which the premium is paid in the future on the condition that the price of the underlying is trading away from a specified level. In other words, a call option will have its premium paid only when the spot rate is below a preset level, while the premium of a put option will be payable when the spot rate exceeds a preset level. In foreign exchange markets, a forward reversing option is the same as a straight FOREX option except that the option premium is paid in the future contingent on the FOREX price being above or below a specified level.

 

Basket option- A basket option is a type of financial derivative where the underlying asset is a group, or basket, of commodities, securities, or currencies. As with other options, a basket option gives the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specific price, on or before a certain date.

Question 9
What is the term used popularly for the situation when a speculator, being dominant in the market, expects a drop in the value of a particular currency and he begins selling it forward?
  • A.International Fisher Effect
  • B.Bandwagon Effect
  • C.Interest Rate Parity Effect
  • D.Relative Version Effect
Correct Answer: Bandwagon Effect

Bandwagon Effect -When a speculator being dominant in the market expects a drop in the value of a particular currency, he begins selling it forward. The other speculators follow the lead.

 

The Interest Rate Parity (IRP) is a theory that states that the size of the forward premium (or discount) should be equal to the interest rate differential between the two countries of concern. When IRP exists, covered interest arbitrage is not feasible because any interest rate advantage in the foreign country will be offset by the discount on the forward rate. Thus, the act of covered interest arbitrage would generate a return that is no higher than what would be generated by a domestic investment.

 

International Fisher Effect states that the difference between the nominal interest rates in two countries is directly proportional to the changes in the exchange rate of their currencies at any given time.

Question 10
Letters of Credit, Guarantees, Forward Contracts etc., come under which one of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Liabilities of a bank
  • B.Assets of a bank
  • C.Foreign exchange items of a bank
  • D.Off-balance sheet items of a bank
Correct Answer: Off-balance sheet items of a bank

Off-balance sheet (OBS) items is a term for assets or liabilities that do not appear on a company's balance sheet. Although not recorded on the balance sheet, they are still assets and liabilities of the company. Off-balance sheet items are typically those not owned by or are a direct obligation of the company. For example, when loans are securitized and sold off as investments, the secured debt is often kept off the bank's books. An operating lease is one of the most common off-balance items.

 

Off balance sheet items of a bank include all derivative products (including interest rate swaps) as admissible. Also includes inter alia items like (a) claims against the bank not acknowledged as debt, (b) liability for partly paid investments, (c) bills re-discounted and (d) letters of credit.

Question 11
The certificate which evidences an unsecured corporate debt of short-term maturity, is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Certificate of Deposit
  • B.Short-term loan certificate
  • C.Treasury Bill
  • D.Commercial paper
Correct Answer: Commercial paper

The Commercial Paper, CP is an unsecured money market instrument issued in the form of promissory note. This was introduced in 1990 with an objective to enable highly rated corporate borrowers to diversify their sources of short-term borrowings and provide an additional instrument to the investors. The CP usually has a maturity period of 7 days to 1 year. Companies including NBFCs and All India Financial Institutions (AIFIs), other entities, such as co-operative societies/unions, government entities, trusts, limited liability partnerships and any other body corporate are eligible to issue CPs.

The Certificate of Deposit (CD) is a negotiable money market instrument and issued in dematerialised form or as a Usance Promissory Note against funds deposited at a bank or other eligible financial institution for a specified time period. The CDs can be issued by Scheduled Commercial Banks (excluding RRBs and LABs), and selected All India Financial Institutions (AIFIs). The tenure of CD ranges from 7 days to 1 year.

The Treasury Bills (T-Bills) are used by the Central Government to fulfill its short-term liquidity requirement upto the period of 364 days. They are also known as Zero Coupon Bonds (pays no interest) issued by the RBI on behalf of the Central Government. T-Bills are issued in the form of a promissory note. They are highly liquid and have assured yield and negligible risk of default. They are issued at a price which is lower than their face value and repaid at par.

A short term loan is a type of loan that is obtained to support a temporary personal or business capital need. As it is a type of credit, it involves a borrowed capital amount and interest that needs to be returned or paid back at a given due date, which is usually within a year from getting the loan.

Question 12
Match the various stock exchanges in List – I with the years of their establishment in List – II as follows and suggest the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)List – Ia. National Stock Exchange (NSE)b. MCX Stock Exchange (MCX-SX)c. Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE)d. Interconnected Stock Exchange of India (ISEI)List – IIi. 1875ii. 1992iii. 2000iv. 2008Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-ii b-iv c-i d-iii
  • B.a-ii b-iii c-iv d-i
  • C.a-i b-iii c-ii d-iv
  • D.a-iii b-ii c-iv d-i
Correct Answer: a-ii b-iv c-i d-iii

Correct match is given below.

 

a. National Stock Exchange (NSE) – ii. 1992

b. MCX Stock Exchange (MCX-SX) – iv. 2008

c. Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) – i. 1875

d. Interconnected Stock Exchange of India (ISEI) – iii. 2000

Question 13
Consider the following statements. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)Assertion ‘A’:A well-developed money market is the basis for an effective monetary policy. It is in the money market that the Central Bank comes into contact with the financial sectors of the economy as a whole and it is through the liquidity in the market that influences the cost and availability of credit.Reasoning ‘R’:A well-organized money market is an essential condition for the successful operation of the Central Banking policies, and for holding the conditions of liquidity within the bounds of what the monetary authorities consider desirable.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.A is true but R is false
  • B.R is true but A is false
  • C.A is true and R offers correct explanation to A
  • D.Both A and R are false
Correct Answer: A is true and R offers correct explanation to A

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Assertion emphasizes the importance of a well-developed money market as the basis for an effective monetary policy. It correctly points out that the money market is where the Central Bank interacts with the financial sectors of the economy, and through liquidity, it influences the cost and availability of credit. This statement is true.

 

Reason supports the Assertion by stating that a well-organized money market is essential for the successful operation of Central Banking policies and for maintaining liquidity within the bounds considered desirable by monetary authorities. In essence, it provides a valid explanation for the importance of a well-developed money market. This statement is also true.

 

Therefore, Assertion ‘A’ is true, and reasoning ‘R’ provides a correct explanation for ‘A’.

Question 14
Preference share in India is issued by a company for a maximum period of: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.10 years
  • B.15 years
  • C.20 years
  • D.Unlimited period.
Correct Answer: 20 years

Preference shares are those shares which have rights of preference over equity shares in case of distribution of dividend and distribution of surplus in the case of winding up.

As per the Companies Act 2013, present preference shares can be issued for a maximum period of 20 years.

Question 15
Which one of the following is false with respect to interest rate structure in the Indian Money Market? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.A very tight liquidity position will increase the call rates while excess liquidity will give fairly low and stable rates.
  • B.If the liquidity crunch of the banks is passed on to the system, it may lead to high volatility in the call rates.
  • C.Call rates under normal liquidity conditions are the cap rate for the term money market.
  • D.In a volatile call market situation, lending will yield high return and by selling Inter-bank participation, the bank will have more money to play in the call market.
Correct Answer: Call rates under normal liquidity conditions are the cap rate for the term money market.

Option (C) is false regarding the interest rate structure in the Indian Money Market.

 

Call rates represent the interest rates at which banks lend and borrow funds among themselves on an overnight basis. However, stating that call rates under normal liquidity conditions are the cap rate for the term money market is incorrect. Call rates are not a definitive cap rate for the term money market. Term money rates depend on various factors beyond the overnight interbank lending rates.

 

The other options generally describe the relationship between liquidity conditions and call rates, the impact of liquidity crunch on call rates' volatility, and strategies of banks in a volatile call market situation.

Question 16
Which among the following is NOT a correct statement? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Hedge funds are not mutual funds
  • B.Hedge funds can be sold to public
  • C.Investors in mutual funds must pay various fees and expenses
  • D.Mutual funds provide economics of scale to investment decisions
Correct Answer: Hedge funds can be sold to public

Option B is the correct answer.

 

(A) Hedge funds are not mutual funds: This statement is correct. Hedge funds and mutual funds are distinct types of investment funds with different structures, investment strategies, and regulatory requirements.

 

(B) Hedge funds can be sold to the public: This statement is not correct. Hedge funds are typically private investment funds that are not open to the general public. They are often limited to sophisticated and high-net-worth investors due to regulatory restrictions.

 

(C) Investors in mutual funds must pay various fees and expenses: This statement is correct. Mutual funds charge fees and expenses, which may include management fees, administrative fees, and other costs associated with managing the fund.

 

(D) Mutual funds provide economics of scale to investment decisions: This statement is correct. Mutual funds pool the funds of many investors to invest in a diversified portfolio of securities, providing economies of scale and spreading risk among a larger group of investors.

 

Therefore option (B) is NOT a correct statement as hedge funds are typically not sold to the public.

Question 17
14 Days intermediate T-bills were brought into effect from 1996-97 after the abolition of which of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.91 Days T-bills
  • B.182 Days T-bills
  • C.273 Days T-bills
  • D.364 Days T-bills
Correct Answer: 91 Days T-bills

14 Days intermediate T-bills were introduced in 1996-97 after the abolition of 91 Days T-bills. The 91-days T-bills, which were previously available on tap, were replaced by this alternative 14-day instrument. These intermediate T-bills were limited to State Governments, foreign central banks, and specified bodies. They were non-transferable and issued only in book entry forms to be redeemed at par. However, they have been discontinued due to a lack of public response.

Question 18
Following are the events which generally happen in the life of a public limited company: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)(a) Public issue of shares (IPO)(b) Firm Incorporation(c) Preliminary expenditures(d) Issue of equity shares to promoters of the companyChoose the correct sequence (chronological order) of the events from the options given below:
  • A.a – b – c – d
  • B.b – c – d – a
  • C.c – b – a – d
  • D.c – b – d – a
Correct Answer: c – b – d – a

The correct sequence of events which generally happen in the life of a public limited company are as follows:

Preliminary Expenditures

Firm Incorporation

Issue of equity shares to promoters of the company

Public issue of shares (IPO)

 

Preliminary Expenditure: Before incorporation of a Company, certain preliminary expenses are incurred by promoters of the Company. Preliminary expenses refer to those expenses which are incurred in forming a joint stock company. These comprise the expenses incidental to the creation and floatation of a company.

 

Incorporation: A company comes into existence is generally by a process referred to as incorporation. Once a company has been legally incorporated, it becomes a distinct entity from those who invest their capital and labour to run the company.

 

The moment the Company is incorporated, the first task that is performed is to issue equity shares of the Company to the promoters in lieu of services rendered by them in formation of a company.

 

Initial Public Offer (IPO): An IPO is when a company which is presently not listed at any stock exchange makes either a fresh issue of shares or makes an offer for sale of its existing shares or both for the first time to the public. Through a public offering, the issuer makes an offer for new investors to enter its shareholding family. Going public provides an opportunity to the companies to raise cash for setting up a project or for diversification/expansion or sometimes for working capital or even to retire debt or for potential acquisitions. This is called fresh issue of capital where the proceeds of the issue go to the company.

Question 19
Which one of the following statements is not true about Indian Money Market? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Non-Banking Finance Companies (NBFCs) are regulated by the Ministry of Finance.
  • B.Money market mutual funds are allowed to sell units to corporates and individuals.
  • C.A well-developed money market is essential for a modern economy.
  • D.In the Indian Money Market, the predominant place is enjoyed by government and semi- government securities.
Correct Answer: Non-Banking Finance Companies (NBFCs) are regulated by the Ministry of Finance.

The Reserve Bank regulates and supervises the NBFCs in terms of Chapter III B of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934. The Reserve Bank has put in place a set of directions to regulate the activities of NBFCs under its jurisdiction.

 

Money market is specifically for short term funds whose period of maturity is up to 1 year.

 

A well-developed money market is essential for a modern economy. In the Indian Money Market, the predominant place is enjoyed by government and semi-government securities.

 

Money market mutual funds (MMF) invest in short-term debt instruments which include cash, cash equivalent securities, and high-credit-rating, debt-based securities with a short-term maturity that are rated high. Money market mutual funds are allowed to sell units to corporates and individuals.

Question 20
Which of the following distinction(s) is/are not correct between public issue and rights issue? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) In public issue, application for shares are invited from the general public and in rights issue, the shares are offered to existing shareholder.(2) In public issue, there is no question of any over-subscription and in in rights issue the shares may be under subscribed or oversubscribed leading to prorate allotment.(3) The price of public issue is generally less than the market price and in rights issue, the price is deliberately made less than the market price.(4) In a public issue, the communication of the issue is through prospects or advertisements and in rights issue the communication is between the company and the existing numbers of the company.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.2 only
  • B.4 only
  • C.1 and 3 only
  • D.3 and 4 only
Correct Answer: 2 only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

(1) In public issue, application for shares are invited from the general public and in rights issue, the shares are offered to existing shareholders.

This statement is correct. In a public issue, shares are offered to the general public, while in a rights issue, shares are offered to existing shareholders.

 

(2) In public issue, there is no question of any oversubscription, and in rights issue, the shares may be under-subscribed or oversubscribed, leading to prorate allotment.

This statement is not correct. Both public issues and rights issues can be oversubscribed or undersubscribed. Oversubscription occurs when the demand for shares exceeds the number of shares available. In a rights issue, prorate allotment may be used to allocate shares in case of oversubscription.

 

(3) The price of the public issue is generally less than the market price, and in the rights issue, the price is deliberately made less than the market price.

This statement is correct. In a public issue, the issue price is often set at a discount to the prevailing market price to attract investors. In a rights issue, the price is typically set lower than the market price to incentivize existing shareholders to exercise their rights.

 

(4) In a public issue, the communication of the issue is through prospects or advertisements, and in a rights issue, the communication is between the company and the existing members of the company.

This statement is correct. In a public issue, communication is directed at the general public through prospectuses and advertisements. In a rights issue, communication is typically between the company and its existing shareholders.

Question 21
Arrange the following steps in logical sequence of operation of the registration of Portfolio Managers: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. Prior approval of the SEBI.2. Adequate steps for redressal of investors grievances.3. Maintenance of the specified capital adequacy requirements.4. Payment of Fee.5.) Abide by the regulations under the SEBI Act.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.Codes:
  • A.3, 5, 1, 2, 4
  • B.4, 1, 2, 5, 3
  • C.1, 4, 2, 3, 5
  • D.4, 5, 1, 3, 2
Correct Answer: 1, 4, 2, 3, 5

A portfolio manager is a person or group of people responsible for investing a mutual, exchange traded or closed-end fund’s assets, implementing its investment strategy, and 'managing day-to-day portfolio trading.

 

The following steps in logical sequence of operation of the registration of portfolio managers:

1. Prior approval of the SEBI.

2. Payment of Fee.

3. Adequate steps for redressal of investors’ grievances.

4. Maintenance of the specified capital adequacy requirements

5. Abide by the regulations under the SEBI Act.

 

Hence, option C is the correct answer.

Question 22
Which of the following is NOT the feature of the Indian capital market? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Government rules and regulations
  • B.Utilises intermediaries
  • C.Link between savers and investment opportunities
  • D.Co‐promotes state‐level venture funds
Correct Answer: Co‐promotes state‐level venture funds

Capital market is market for medium- and long-term funds which have maturity period of more than 1 year.

 

Features of Indian Capital Market are –

1. Low liquidity

2. High Risk

3. Long term

4. Bounded by Government rules and regulations

5. Utilises intermediaries

6. Link between savers and investment opportunities

 

Indian capital market does not co‐promotes state‐level venture funds. Issue of State government bond and dated securities known as State Development Loans (SDL) is a feature of Indian capital market.

Hence, option D is the correct answer.

Question 23
Which of the following statements is false?
  • A.Capital market is a market for medium- and long-term funds.
  • B.GDR is a negotiable instrument issued by a US bank.
  • C.Many publicly listed companies in India trades their shares through Bombay Stock Exchange or National Stock Exchange.
  • D.Securities that are listed on various stock exchanges are eligible for being traded there, are called listed securities.
Correct Answer: GDR is a negotiable instrument issued by a US bank.

Capital market is market for medium- and long-term funds which have maturity period of more than 1 year. Hence, statement A is correct.

 

GDR (Global Depository Receipt) is a negotiable instrument issued by a foreign depository bank to an Indian company. Indian companies can trade their shares on international exchanges other than US through GDR. The depository bank can convert the GDR into shares and trade them on their domestic stock exchange. ADR (American Depository Receipt) is a negotiable instrument issued by US bank. Hence statement B is incorrect.

 

There are various stock exchanges in India and BSE (Bombay Stock Exchange) and NSE (National Stock Exchange) are the oldest and largest one. Many publicly listed companies in India trades their shares through Bombay stock exchange or National stock exchange. Hence, statement C is also correct.

 

Securities that are listed on various stock exchanges are eligible for being traded there, are called listed securities. Hence, statement D is correct.

 

Hence, option B is the correct answer.

Question 24
Which of the following refers to default-risk intermediation? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.Borrowing short-term funds from savers and making long-term loans to borrowers.
  • B.Making loans to risky borrowers by attracting savings from the savers who are risk-averse.
  • C.Using information gathering skills of the intermediary.
  • D.Pooling small amounts of savings from individuals to give loans to others
Correct Answer: Making loans to risky borrowers by attracting savings from the savers who are risk-averse.

Default-risk intermediation refers to the process by which financial intermediaries such as banks or other lending institutions make loans to risky borrowers while attracting savings from risk-averse savers. This process involves taking on credit risk in order to generate profits by charging higher interest rates to risky borrowers than the interest paid to savers.

 

In a default-risk intermediation process, the financial intermediaries act as a middleman between savers and borrowers, managing the risk of lending and investing on behalf of their clients.

 

Savers deposit their funds with these intermediaries, who use these funds to make loans to borrowers who may be unable to obtain financing elsewhere due to their high risk profiles.

 

These borrowers are willing to pay a higher interest rate to compensate the intermediaries for the added risk of default. Meanwhile, the intermediaries use their expertise to evaluate the creditworthiness of the borrowers and take measures to mitigate the risk of default. They may require collateral or impose stricter loan covenants to reduce the risk of default and protect the interests of their savers.

 

By taking on the risk of default, intermediaries can generate profits from the interest rate spread between the rates paid to savers and the rates charged to borrowers. This intermediation process allows risk-averse savers to earn a return on their savings while providing financing to risky borrowers who may be excluded from the credit market.

 

However, default-risk intermediation can also lead to potential problems if the intermediaries do not properly assess the creditworthiness of the borrowers or manage the risk of default effectively. This can lead to defaults and losses for the intermediaries and their savers. Therefore, it is important for intermediaries to have proper risk management systems in place to ensure that they can continue to provide default-risk intermediation services in a sustainable and profitable manner.

Question 25
Which of the following are related to primary capital market? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)a. IPOb. Long Term Loansc. Venture Capitald. Letters of Credite. Participation CertificatesChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b and e only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a, b and c only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and c only

The primary capital market is a market where new securities are issued and sold for the first time.

 

Following are related to the primary capital market:

a. IPO (Initial Public Offering): An IPO is the first time a company issues shares to the public. It is one of the most common ways for a company to raise capital.

b. Long Term Loans: Companies can raise capital by taking long-term loans from banks or other financial institutions.

c. Venture Capital: Venture capital is a type of private equity financing provided to early-stage companies with high growth potential.

d. Letters of Credit: Letters of credit are used in international trade to ensure that payment will be made. They are not related to the primary capital market.

e. Participation Certificates: Participation certificates are debt securities issued by financial institutions. They are not related to the primary capital market.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option C.

Question 26
Match the following List - I with the List - II. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)List – I (Name of Securities)(a) Bonds of Land Development Banks(b) Treasury Bills(c) Shares of a Public Ltd. Co.List – II (Type of Securities)(i) Semi Government Securities(ii) First Order Securities(iii) Personal SecuritiesSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-i b-ii c-iii
  • B.a-ii b-i c-iii
  • C.a-iii b-ii c-i
  • D.a-i b-iii c-ii
Correct Answer: a-i b-ii c-iii

The correct match is given below.

(a) Bonds of Land Development Banks - Semi Government Securities

(b) Treasury Bills - First Order Securities

(c) Shares of a Public Ltd. Co. - Personal Securities

Question 27
“De-coupling” denotes: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2009)
  • A.Indian market may be cut off from global markets so that it may not be affected by global volatility.
  • B.separating the birds affected by bird-flu.
  • C.that markets are independent.
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Indian market may be cut off from global markets so that it may not be affected by global volatility.

"De-coupling" in the context of financial markets typically refers to the idea that the performance of one market, such as the Indian market, can be somewhat independent or insulated from the global markets. It suggests that a particular market may not be as affected by global economic events or volatility.

Question 28
Which among the following information shall be disclosed for all public issues of shares irrespective of their issue price? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)A. Earnings per shareB. Dividend payout ratioC. Pre-issue P/E ratioD. Average return on net worth in last 3 yearsE. Net asset value per share based on last balance sheetChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D and E only
  • B.A, C, D and E only
  • C.B, C, D and E only
  • D.A, B, C and D only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E only

Option B is the correct answer.

 

AS per SEBI guidelines, the basis for issue price, floor price or price band, as the case may be, shall be disclosed and justified by the issuer in consultation with the lead merchant banker on the basis of the following information, which shall be also disclosed separately:

 

(a) Earnings per Share and Diluted Earnings per Share, pre-issue, for the last 3 years (as adjusted for changes in capital).

(b) Price Earnings ratio pre-issue.

(c) Average Return on Net Worth in the last 3 years.

(d) Minimum Return on Increased Net Worth required to maintain pre-issue Earnings per Share.

(e) Net Asset Value per share based on last balance sheet.

(f) Net Asset Value per share after issue and comparison thereof with the issue price.

Question 29
Which of the following statements is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.The oldest stock exchange of India is OTCEI.
  • B.Sensex is an index number of 30 scrips.
  • C.In book-building process, the price of the security is announced by the company.
  • D.Futures and options in shares are traded at all stock exchanges of India.
Correct Answer: Sensex is an index number of 30 scrips.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The S&P BSE Sensex comprises 30 actively traded stocks from various sectors of the Indian economy. These 30 stocks are considered to be representative of the broader market trends in India. The index is calculated using the free-float market capitalization methodology, where the level of index at any point in time reflects the total free-float market value of all the stocks in the index relative to a particular base period.

Question 30
The acronym SRO, being used in the capital market for various market participants, stands for which one of the following?
  • A.Self-Regulatory Organisations
  • B.Small Revenue Operators
  • C.Securities Roll-back Operators
  • D.Securities Regulatory Organisations
Correct Answer: Self-Regulatory Organisations

A Self-Regulatory Organization (SRO) is an entity such as a non-governmental organization, which has the power to create and enforce stand-alone industry and professional regulations and standards on its own. In the case of financial SROs, such as a stock exchange, the priority is to protect investors by establishing rules, regulations, and set standards of procedures which promote ethics, equality, and professionalism.

Although SROs can be privately owned, the government can still dictate their broader policies. In India, it is done by Security and Exchange Board of India (SEBI). Industries can band together and start their own SROs, which allow them to maintain competitiveness and safety concerns if there is a lack of governmental oversight.

Question 31
Match the items of List - I with the items of List - II and select a correct code:List – I(a) SEBI(b) RBI(c) STCI(d) OTCEIList – II(i) Exchange for small companies(ii) Secondary market in treasury bills(iii) Regulation of secondary market(iv) Ad-hoc treasury billsSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)

SEBI- The main function of SEBI is to regulate secondary market i.e. capital market in India.

 

RBI- The system of ad-hoc treasury bills was controlled by RBI prior to 1997. As per the Agreement signed between the Reserve Bank of India and Government of India on September 9, 1994, the system of ad-hoc Treasury Bills is to be discontinued by 1997-98. The Budget for 1997-98 has announced the decision to introduce a new system upon the discontinuation of the ad-hoc Treasury Bills from the financial year 1997-98.

 

STCI- In May 1994, STCI Finance Limited was promoted by RBI with the main objective of fostering an active secondary market in Government of India Securities and Public Sector bonds. RBI owned a majority stake of 50.18% in the paid up share capital of the company. In 1996, the Company was accredited as the first Primary Dealer in the India. As one of the leading Primary Dealers in the country, the Company was a market maker in government securities, corporate bonds and money market instruments.

 

OTCEI- The OTC Exchange Of India (OTCEI), also known as the Over-the-Counter Exchange of India, is based in Mumbai, Maharashtra. It is India's first exchange for small companies, as well as the first screen-based nationwide stock exchange in India. OTCEI was set up to access high-technology enterprising promoters in raising finance for new product development in a cost-effective manner and to provide a transparent and efficient trading system to investors.

Quiz Attempt #118905

Total Questions: 37
Question 1
Match List-I and List-II(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)List I (Institutions)A. National Housing BankB. Industrial Development Bank of IndiaC. Small Industrial Development Bank of IndiaD. Industrial Finance Corporation of IndiaList II (Date of establishment)I. 01 – 07 – 1964II. 01 – 07 – 1948III. 02 – 04 – 1990IV. 09 – 07 – 1988Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- I, B-II, C- III, D-IV
  • B.A- III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A- I, B- IV, C-III, D-II
  • D.A- IV, B-I, C-III, D-II
Correct Answer: A- IV, B-I, C-III, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

List I (Institutions) – List II (Date of establishment)

A. National Housing Bank - 09 – 07 – 1988

B. Industrial Development Bank of India - 01 – 07 – 1964

C. Small Industrial Development Bank of India - 02 – 04 – 1990

D. Industrial Finance Corporation of India - 01 – 07 – 1948

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 2
Arrange the following Financial Institution in the increasing order of their date of establishment-(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)A. NABARDB. EXIM BankC. UTID. SIDBIE. ECGCChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.C, B, A, D, E
  • C.C, A, B, E, D
  • D.E, C, B, A, D
Correct Answer: E, C, B, A, D

The following Financial Institution in the increasing order of their date of establishment-

E. ECGC – 30 July 1957

C. UTI - 1963

B. EXIM Bank – 1 January 1982

A. NABARD – 12 July 1982

D. SIDBI – 2 April 1990

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D), i.e., E, C, B, A, D.

Question 3
Arrange the following institutions in ascending order of their year of establishment:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)A. SEBIB. Reserve Bank of IndiaC. State Bank of IndiaD. SIDBIE. NABARDChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, B, E, A, D
  • B.B, C, E, D, A
  • C.B, C, A, E, D
  • D.E, B, C, D, A
Correct Answer: B, C, E, D, A

The correct order based on the year of establishment is:

Reserve Bank of India (B) – 1935

State Bank of India (C) – 1955

NABARD (E) – 1982

SIDBI (D) – 1990

SEBI (A) – 1992

Question 4
Which of the followings are the national financial institutions?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)(A) Industrial Development Bank of India(B) Industrial Finance Corporation of India(C) The State Industrial Development Corporation(D) United Nations Development Programme(E) State Financial CorporationsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(A), (B) and (C) Only
  • B.(B), (C) and (D) Only
  • C.(A), (B), (C) and (E) Only
  • D.(A), (C), (D) and (E) Only
Correct Answer: (A), (B), (C) and (E) Only

Option C is the correct answer.

 

(A) Industrial Development Bank of India (IDBI): This is a well-known national financial institution established to provide credit and other financial services for the development of industry in India.

 

(B) Industrial Finance Corporation of India (IFCI): This is one of India's oldest development finance institutions, established to provide financial assistance for industrial development.

 

(C) The State Industrial Development Corporation (SIDC): These are state-level financial institutions created to promote industrial development within individual states in India. Though they operate at the state level, they are part of the broader national financial framework.

 

(D) United Nations Development Programme (UNDP): This is an international organization working globally to eradicate poverty and reduce inequalities through sustainable development. It is not a national financial institution in India.

 

(E) State Financial Corporations (SFCs): These are state-level financial institutions established to provide financial assistance to small and medium-scale industries within the states of India. Similar to SIDCs, they are integral to the national financial infrastructure despite operating at the state level.

 

Given the analysis, the entities that qualify as national financial institutions in India are (A), (B), (C), and (E).

Question 5
Arrange the financial institutions according to their formation from latest to earliest.(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. Industrial Finance Corporation of IndiaB. Regional Rural BankC. National Bank for Agriculture and Rural DevelopmentD. National Industrial Development CorporationE. The Reserve Bank of IndiaChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.B, C, A, D, E
  • B.C, B, D, A, E
  • C.B, D, E, C, A
  • D.A, B, C, D, E
Correct Answer: C, B, D, A, E

The financial institutions according to their formation from latest to earliest are as follows.

A. Industrial Finance Corporation of India - 1948

B. Regional Rural Bank - 1975

C. National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development - 1982

D. National Industrial Development Corporation - 1954

E. The Reserve Bank of India – 1935

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (B), C, B, D, A, E.

Question 6
Which of the following are operational methodology ofSelf HelpGroup?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. Village meeting of women in village by MFIB. Group formationC. Group training for 5-7 days on procedures and business development skillsD. Group meeting once a week for mobilizing saving, disbursing and repaying loans.E. Lending money for long term loansChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, B, C and D only
  • D.B, C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D only

The operational methodologies of Self Help Groups (SHGs) include:

 

A. Village meeting of women in the village by MFI: This helps raise awareness and interest among potential members.

 

B. Group formation: This is essential for creating the SHG structure.

 

C. Group training for 5-7 days on procedures and business development skills: Training is crucial for empowering members with the necessary skills.

 

D. Group meeting once a week for mobilizing saving, disbursing, and repaying loans: Regular meetings are important for managing savings and loans effectively.

 

E. Lending money for long-term loans: While SHGs may engage in lending, it focuses more on short-term loans and micro-financing rather than long-term loans.

 

Since options A, B, C, and D directly relate to the operational methodologies of SHGs, the correct answer is (C) A, B, C and D only.

Question 7
The following statements relate to Mudra Yojana:Statement I:Mudra is an NBFC supporting development scheme of micro enterprise sector in the country. It provides refinance support to Bank/MFIs for lending to micro units having loan requirement up to Rs. 10 lakhs.Statement II:Mudra has created different products/schemes for refinancing loans. These interventions have been named Shishu, Kishore, and Tarun to signify the state of growth/development and funding needs of the beneficiary micro unit/entrepreneur.Which of the following options is correct?
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect
  • B.Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect
  • C.Both the statements I and II are correct
  • D.Both the statements I and II are incorrect
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Pradhan Mantri MUDRA Yojana (PMMY)

The Pradhan Mantri MUDRA Yojana (PMMY) was launched in April 2015 for providing loans upto Rs 10 lakh to the non-corporate, non-farm small/micro enterprises. These loans are classified as MUDRA loans under PMMY. These loans are given by Commercial Banks, RRBs, Small Finance Banks, Cooperative Banks, MFIs and NBFCs.

 

Micro Units Development & Refinance Agency Ltd. (MUDRA) has been set up as a wholly owned subsidiary of SIDBI for “funding the unfunded” micro enterprises in the country. MUDRA is a refinancing institution hence does not lend directly to borrowers but provided loans to micro-finance institution and NBFCs.

 

Under the aegis of PMMY, MUDRA has created 3 products namely:

Shishu: covering loans up to Rs. 50,000.

Kishor: covering loans above Rs. 50,000 and up to Rs. 5 lakhs.

Tarun: covering loans above Rs. 5 lakhs and up to Rs. 10 lakhs

 

The loans under Mudra Scheme are guaranteed by Credit Guarantee Fund for Micro Units (CGFMU) and the same is provided through National Credit Guarantee Trustee Company (NCGTC) Ltd (a private Company under Department of Financial Services, Ministry of Finance, set up in 2014).

Question 8
Industrial Reconstruction Bank of India (IRBI) which was reconstituted into a full-fledged all-purpose developmental financial institution with effect from March 27, 1997 was renamed as _______. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)
  • A.Small Industrial Development Bank of India
  • B.Industrial Investment Bank of India Ltd.
  • C.Industrial Finance Corporation of India
  • D.Board of Industrial and Financial Reconstruction
Correct Answer: Industrial Investment Bank of India Ltd.

The Industrial Investment Bank of India was a government of India-owned financial investment institution. It was established in 1971 by resolution of the Parliament of India u/s 617 of the Companies Act.

 

With a view to converting the institution into a full-fledged development financial institution, IRBI was incorporated under the Companies Act 1956, as Industrial Investment Bank of India Ltd. (IIBI) in March 1997. IIBI offered a wide range of products and services, including term loan assistance for project finance, short duration non-project asset-backed financing, working capital/other short-term loans to companies, equity subscription, asset credit, equipment finance and investments in capital market and money market instruments.

Question 9
Which of the following is the main function of State Financial Corporations?
  • A.Provide short-term finance to large-sized industrial units
  • B.Provide long-term finance to small and medium sized industrial units.
  • C.Undertake variety of promotional activities, like preparation of feasibility reports, conducting industrial potential surveys, etc.
  • D.Develop industrial estates for providing land to a building Entrepreneurs
Correct Answer: Provide long-term finance to small and medium sized industrial units.

In order to meet the financial needs of small and medium scale industrial units which are not governed by Industrial Finance Corporation, the Government of India passed State Finance Corporation Act in 1951, empowering the State Governments to start financial corporations. The First State Financial Corporation was set up in Punjab in the year 1953. At present there are 18 SFCs operating in the country.

 

Following are the various functions of SFCs:

a) Financial Assistance to Small Units: The main function of State Finance Corporations is to provide long term finance to small and medium scale Industrial concerns formed as public or private limited companies, corporations, forms or proprietary concerns repayable with in a period of 20 years.

b) Guaranteeing Loans: The SFCs guarantee loans raised by industrial concerns from commercial banks and cooperative banks repayable within a period of 20 years.

c) Subscription and Underwriting: The State Finance Corporations subscribes to the debentures issued by the industrial concerns repayable within 20 years and also underwrites the issue of stock, shares, bonds and debentures of industrial concerns.

d) Guarantee for deferred Payments: They guarantees the deferred payments for the purchase of plant, machinery etc within the country.

e) Acting as Agent of Central and State Governments: They act as an agent of the central or state governments or some industrial financing institutions for sanctioning and disbursing loans to small industries.

Question 10
The Government of India established the Small Industries Development Organization (SIDO) in the year: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.1951
  • B.1972
  • C.1954
  • D.1982
Correct Answer: 1954

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The Small Industries Development Organization (SIDO) is the national SME Development Agency of India. It is a major constituent of the Ministry of Small Scale Industries of the Government of India. A senior official of the Government of India, who is designated as the Development Commissioner for Small Scale Industries (DCSSI), heads SIDO. He is also the ex-officio Additional Secretary in the Ministry of Small Scale Industries; that is, he is second in command in the bureaucratic hierarchy of the Ministry. Set up in 1954, SIDO provides services to small industry throughout the country by implementing a broad program of activities and services

 

Note that, SIDO is now known as the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises – Development Organization (MSME-DO).

Question 11
Which one of the following is an apex organization under the union ministry of MSME engaged in Training, Consultancy, Research and Publication to promote entrepreneurship? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.NIESBUD
  • B.NIMSME
  • C.IIE
  • D.MGIRI
Correct Answer: NIESBUD

The National Institute for Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development, NIESBUD is a premier organization of the Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship, engaged in training, consultancy, research, etc. in order to promote entrepreneurship. The major activities of the Institute are Training of Trainers, Management Development Programmes, Entrepreneurship-cum-Skill Development Programmes, Entrepreneurship Development Programmes and Cluster Intervention.

Question 12
SIDBI has been entrusted with the responsibility of: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT 2013)
  • A.Providing financial assistance to all sectors.
  • B.Developing medium and large scale industry.
  • C.Providing incentives to medium scale industry.
  • D.Developing and supporting small business.
Correct Answer: Developing and supporting small business.

Option D is the most appropriate answer.

 

Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) set up on 2nd April 1990 under an Act of Indian Parliament, acts as the Principal Financial Institution for Promotion, Financing and Development of the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise (MSME) sector as well as for co-ordination of functions of institutions engaged in similar activities.

Question 13
State Financial Corporation Act encourages in: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Establishing Industrial Estates
  • B.Establishing small and medium size industries
  • C.Establishing Agricultural Farms
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: Establishing small and medium size industries

In order to meet the financial needs of small and medium scale industrial units which are not governed by Industrial Finance Corporation, the Government of India passed State Finance Corporation Act in 1951, empowering the State Governments to start financial corporations. The First State Financial Corporation was set up in Punjab in the year 1953.

 

Main functions are discussed below.

a) Financial Assistance to Small Units: The main function of State Finance Corporations is to provide long term finance to small and medium scale Industrial concerns formed as public or private limited companies, corporations, forms or proprietary concerns repayable with in a period of 20 years.

b) Guaranteeing Loans: The SFCs guarantee loans raised by industrial concerns from commercial banks and cooperative banks repayable within a period of 20 years.

c) Subscription and Underwriting: The State Finance Corporations subscribes to the debentures issued by the industrial concerns repayable within 20 years and also underwrites the issue of stock, shares, bonds and debentures of industrial concerns.

d) Guarantee for deferred Payments: They guarantees the deferred payments for the purchase of plant, machinery etc within the country.

e) Acting as Agent of Central and State Governments: They act as an agent of the central or state governments or some industrial financing institutions for sanctioning and disbursing loans to small industries.

Question 14
Federation of Associations of Small Industries of India (FASII) promoted in 1959 is which one of the following type?
  • A.Government organization
  • B.Liaisoning organization
  • C.Small Scale unit
  • D.SSI Board
Correct Answer: Liaisoning organization

The Federation of Associations of Small Industries of India (FASII) is a consequence of the visit of the Ford Foundation Team to India in 1953 which emphasized the need for a national apex body for Micro, Small, Village, Cottage and Rural Enterprises. FASII was ushered into existence in the year 1959 under the sponsorship of the Government of India.

 

Liaisoning organization refers to an entity that acts as a link or intermediary between different groups or organizations. In this case, the Federation of Associations of Small Industries of India (FASII) is described as a Liaisoning organization.

 

A liaisoning organization typically facilitates communication and coordination between various stakeholders, such as small industries, government bodies, and other relevant entities. It plays a role in representing the interests of a particular group or industry to ensure effective communication and collaboration.

Question 15
Match the following.List Ia. Central Manufacturing Instituteb. Central Pulp and Paper Research Institutec. Central Leather Research Instituted. Electronic Service and Training CentreList IIA. Deals with paper industryB. Deals with pollution control in Indian TanneriesC. Deals with Machine ToolsD. Deals with training, technical and consultancy servicesSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-A, b-B, c-C, d-D
  • B.a-C, b-A, b-B, d-D
  • C.a-B, b-C, c-D, d-A
  • D.a-D, b-C, c-A, d-B
Correct Answer: a-C, b-A, b-B, d-D

a) Central Manufacturing Institute – CMTI is an R & D organization focusing its efforts mainly on harnessing know-how in the manufacturing technology sector to practical purposes and assisting technological growth in the country. CMTI has the role of being a Catalyst and a Key Player in manufacturing technology growth in the country.

 

b) Central Pulp and Paper Research Institute – Central Pulp & Paper Research Institute, a National level Institute was established in 1980 as an autonomous body under the administrative control of Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion, Ministry of Commerce and Industry, Govt. of India to promote R&D in the field of pulp & paper. The origin of CPPRI dates back to the year 1975 when the UNDP-GOI Project became operational. After the conclusion of the UNDP Project, the facilities thus created were utilized to fulfill the long felt need for R&D needs of Indian Pulp and Paper Industry. Thus after the approval of the Cabinet, Central Pulp & Paper Research Institute (CPPRI) came into existence in November 1980. Existing R&D facilities were continuously upgraded with the aid of Plan Funds received from the Government of India.

 

c) Central Leather Research Institute – Central Leather Research Institute, India was founded on 24 April, 1948. It was a land mark decision of the country born at the mid- night of 15th August 1947, to invest into leather research. In 1947, the export basket of India included mostly raw hides and skins. There remained an untapped opportunity for India in leather sector for economic development, employment generation and export earnings. The missing link was addition of technology to the manufacturing base of Indian leather sector. CLRI was founded to develop an internal strength in the country to generate, assimilate and innovate technologies for leather sector.

It is one matter to design and develop technologies but entirely another to reach viable technologies in a traditional sector like leather. CLRI in 1948, made an initiative with foresight to link technology system with both academy and industry. CLRI assumed the role of being a part of the University of Madras in imparting education in leather technology.

 

d) Electronic Service and Training Centre – Electronics Service & Training Centre has been established as a Govt. of India, Society - registered in April, 1986, under the Societies Registration Act. 1860. As per the Project Document, the main objective of setting up this project is to develop human resources to meet the essential requirements for transfer of technology in assembly and manufacturing of electronics items and parts.

Question 16
Match the following.List-I (Financial Institution)(i) IDBI(ii) SIDBI(iii) NSIC(iv) EDIIList-II (Year of Establishment)I. 1955II. 1964III. 1983IV. 1990Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.(i)-I, (ii)- IV, (iii)-III, (iv)-II
  • B.(i)-II, (ii)-IV, (iii)-I, (iv)-III
  • C.(i)-III, (ii)-I, (iii)-II, (iv)-IV
  • D.(i)-III, (ii)-II, (iii)-I, (iv)-IV
Correct Answer: (i)-II, (ii)-IV, (iii)-I, (iv)-III

Industrial Development Bank of India (IDBI) was established in 1964 by an Act of Parliament to provide credit and other financial facilities for the development of the fledgling Indian industry. It is owned by the government of India.

 

Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI is an independent financial institution aimed to aid the growth and development of micro, small and medium-scale enterprises in India. Set up in 1990 through an act of parliament, it was incorporated initially as a wholly owned subsidiary of Industrial Development Bank of India, IDBI.

 

National Small Industries Corporation Limited (NSIC) is a Mini Ratna PSU established by the Government of India in 1955. It falls under Ministry of Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises of India.

 

The Entrepreneurship Development Institute of India (EDII) an autonomous body and not-for-profit institution, set up in 1983, is sponsored by apex financial institutions, namely the IDBI Bank Ltd, IFCI Ltd. ICICI Ltd and State Bank of India (SBI). EDII is located in Gandhinagar, Gujrat.

Question 17
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Small-scale and Cottage industries ensure a more equitable distribution of the national income.Reasoning ‘R’:The ownership of Small-Scale Industries is more widespread than ownership of large-scale industries and they possess much larger employment potential.Codes: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)
  • A.A is correct, but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect, but R is correct.
  • C.Both A and R are correct, but R is not the right explanation of A.
  • D.Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Cottage and small-scale industrial sector plays a dominant role in the economic development of both developed and developing countries. In developing countries cottage and small-scale industries are especially important in context of employment opportunities, equitable distribution of national income, balanced regional growth and development of rural and semi urban areas. They provide immediate large-scale employment, offer a method of ensuring a more equitable distribution of the national income and facilitate effective mobilization of resources of capital and skill which might otherwise remain unutilized.

 

One of the main arguments put forward in support of the small-scale and cottage industries is that they ensure a more equitable distribution of national income and wealth. This is accomplished because of the following two consideration: (i) the ownership of small-scale industries is more widespread than the ownership of large-scale industries, and (ii) they possess a much larger employment potential as compared to the large industries.

Question 18
